Review Understanding the key factors in high entropy electrocatalysts for an efficient oxygen evolution reaction Ru Wang Writing – original draft a Qiaoling Kang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision a ⁎ Rui Wang Writing – original draft a Quan Zong Writing – review & editing a Lijing Yan Investigation a Xianhe Meng Investigation a Feifan Chang Investigation a Tingli Ma Investigation a Chengbin Jin Supervision a b ⁎ a College of Materials and Chemistry, China Jiliang University, Hangzhou, Zhejiang, 310018 China College of Materials and Chemistry China Jiliang University Hangzhou Zhejiang 310018 China College of Materials and Chemistry, China Jiliang University, Hangzhou 310018, Zhejiang, China b Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education), Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education) Nankai University Tianjin 300071 China Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education), Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract This paper provides the impressive progress in explaining the key factors in the synthesis methods and their influence on structure and OER property of high entropy materials (including complexing agent, synthetic temperature and calcination atmosphere). Furthermore, we emphasize the correlation between composition and OER performance. Modifying the components of high entropy alloys and compounds with heteroatoms (such as O, S, P, N, C, B) to enhance the chemical configurations of active sites, which in turn enhances the intrinsic OER kinetics. In addition, the importance of the electrocatalytic influence mechanism of four core effects (including high entropy effect, lattice distortion effect, cocktail effect and sluggish diffusion effect) on OER performance is emphasized. Ultimately, this work will emphasize the challenges and outline future directions to inform the rational design of HEM electrocatalysts for use in energy conversion devices. High entropy materials (HEMs) show great potential as electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) thanks to their interesting four-core effect. This paper presents the first systematic summary of the key factors in the synthetic methods and their influence on the structure and OER properties of HEMs (including complexing agent, synthetic temperature, and calcination atmosphere). Optimizing the components of high entropy alloys and compounds by introducing heteroatoms (such as O, S, P, N, C, and B) can enhance the chemical configurations of active sites and thus enhance the intrinsic OER kinetics. In addition, this paper emphasizes the importance of the electrocatalytic influence mechanism of the four-core effects (including the high entropy effect, lattice distortion effect, cocktail effect and sluggish diffusion effect) on catalyst structure and their OER performance. Finally, we outline the current challenges and future development directions, aiming to offer crucial insights for creating economical and efficient HEM-based electrocatalysts in the OER field. Keywords High entropy electrocatalysts Key factors Oxygen evolution reaction Four-core effects Influence mechanism 1 Introduction The escalating global energy demand and the excessive reliance on non-renewable fossil fuels have precipitated a multitude of energy and environmental challenges. Consequently, the pursuit of green energy vectors and the investigation into sustainable methods for energy conversion and storage have emerged as pressing and pivotal areas of research. The International Energy Agency (IEA) projects that hydrogen's contribution to the total final energy consumption must escalate to ∼2 % by 2030 and further to ∼10 % by 2050. Such projections underscore the burgeoning demand for hydrogen and its prospective ubiquity across various societal sectors in the forthcoming years [1]. Thus, the pursuit of efficient and sustainable hydrogen production methods has become increasingly crucial. Among these approaches, electrochemical water splitting to generate hydrogen allows for the storage and transportation of clean energy sources like solar, hydropower and wind. This makes it an extremely promising approach to address the energy and environmental issues caused by fossil fuels use [2–4]. The electrochemical decomposition of water involves the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [5]. However, the OER is still the primary constraint in the entire process, owing to its inherently slow four-electron transfer mechanism [6–8]. Moreover, the OER must surmount a substantial energy barrier, resulting in a high overpotential. The “short plate effect” leads to an excessively high overpotential, which impedes the efficiency of electrochemical water splitting and makes the OER one of the most formidable challenges [9,10]. Although noble metal-based materials such as RuO2 and IrO2 have shown high efficiency as OER electrocatalysts, their prohibitive cost and limited availability significantly hinder their largescale commercial application [11,12]. This acts as a powerful impetus to spur the search of non-noble metal-based OER electrocatalysts. It was initially found that transition metals possess excellent catalytic properties and can be inexpensively because they are widely available [13]. However, many transition metal-based catalysts fall short of achieving adequate stability, which poses significant challenges to their industrial application. As fundamental research continues to progress, researchers have discovered a new class of multi principal high entropy materials (HEMs) [14]. These materials consist of five or more elements combined in equiatomic or near-equimolar proportions, with each element contributing from 5% to 35 % [5,15]. Owing to the high entropy effect (thermodynamics), lattice distortion effect (structure), sluggish diffusion effect (kinetics), and the “cocktail effect” (properties), HEMs exhibit superior strength, enhanced wear resistance, and excellent corrosion resistance [16]. Meanwhile, lattice distortion generates additional microstructural defects, while the stable solid solution phase created by the high entropy effect endows the materials with outstanding catalytic performance and stability [17]. Furthermore, the intrinsically complex surface characteristics of HEMs enable a nearly continuous range of adsorption energies at active sites, thus maximizing the proportion of optimally reactive sites [18,19]. HEMs exhibit significant advantages over traditional doped catalysts, as their high configurational entropy gives them excellent phase stability, inhibits elemental segregation and structural degradation, and maintains their activity under harsh reaction conditions. The “cocktail effect” can simultaneously modulate the electronic structure and surface-active sites, whereas conventional doping can only rely on single-element modification. In addition, the unique dynamic reconfiguration property enables the in situ formation of high-entropy active interfaces, which overcomes the shortcomings of traditional catalysts that are prone to deactivation. HEMs also realize the synergistic optimization of multi-parameters, which is difficult to achieve with traditional doping, by flexibly modulating the lattice distortion, electronic structure, and heterogeneous interfaces. These characteristics make HEMs surpass the conventional doped systems in terms of catalytic activity and stability. Taken together, these attributes indicate that HEMs are promising candidates for OER catalysts. Apart from HEMs, medium entropy catalysts (MEMs), low entropy catalysts (LEMs) and noble metal-based catalysts have been reported as excellent candidates. Compared with HEMs, MEMs and LEMs catalysts have relatively small number of components, which also makes them may not be as flexible as HEMs in achieving certain complex performance optimization. While the noble metal-based catalysts have excellent catalytic performance, they have limited active sites, scarce resources and high cost, making them difficult to be applied on a large scale. In order to fully assess the potential of HEMs electrocatalysts for application, a comparative analysis of HEMs, MEMs and LEMs as well as noble metal-based catalysts was performed (Table S1, Supporting Information). HEMs exhibit low overpotentials and high stability by virtue of a multicomponent synergistic effect, and are less costly and more sustainable based on abundant transition metal resources. In the period from 2015 to 2024, there was a market growth in the number of publications and related citations regarding high entropy electrocatalysts, as shown in Fig. 1 a, b. The recently reported high entropy electrocatalysts demonstrate exceptional catalytic activities, and are therefore anticipated to replace costly noble metal catalysts. Following recent achievements, a number of reviews have emerged to summarize these findings [20–22]. However, most of the existing reviews only focused on generalized synthetic methods, compositions, and core effects of HEMs. There are no relevant reports on the key factors of synthetic methods and the influence mechanisms of different high entropy components and core effects for OER in alkaline environments. In view of this, it is necessary to present a thorough, definitive, and analytical review to highlight the key factors in the synthetic methods, the correlation between component and activity, and the electrocatalytic influence mechanisms of core effects. For this purpose, this review focuses on the key elements of the synthetic methods for HEMs and systematically summarizes the important effects of key factors such as complexing agents, synthetic temperature, and calcination atmospheres on the structure and OER properties of HEMs (Fig. 2 ). Furthermore, we emphasize the correlation between composition and OER performance. In the context of optimizing composition, we present the mechanism and role of the introduction of heteroatoms. It is beneficial to adjust the components of high entropy alloys and compounds containing heteroatoms (such as O, S, P, N, C, B) to enhance the chemical configurations of active sites, which can boost the intrinsic OER kinetics. In addition, the electrocatalytic influence mechanisms of four core effects (including the high entropy effect, lattice distortion effect, cocktail effect, and sluggish diffusion effect) of HEMs on OER performance are introduced. Ultimately, this review will highlight the challenges and provide a roadmap for future directions, aiming to inform the rational design of HEMs electrocatalysts for use in energy conversion devices. 2 The influence of synthetic condition of high entropy materials on OER performance HEMs, as an emerging electrocatalyst, have OER properties that are closely related to the composition, microstructure, and electronic structure of the materials, and these key properties are highly dependent on the precise regulation of the synthetic conditions. Therefore, when discussing the impact of HEMs on OER, it is essential to have a thorough understanding of the synthetic methods of these materials and the key factors influencing these methods. Currently, three major synthetic methods are employed for HEMs. The first involves solid-state methods, including traditional solid-state reactions, spark plasma sintering [23], flash sintering [24], ball-milling method [25], mechanochemical synthetic [26], etc. The second utilizes liquid methods, such as sonochemistry-based synthetic, co-precipitation [27], spray pyrolysis [28,29], arc melting [30], and sol–gel combustion [31,32]. The third method employs gaseous approaches, such as magnetron sputtering deposition [33–35]. Table S2 (Supporting Information) provides a comparative analysis of these preparation methods, focusing on cost, scalability, and their influence on material properties. While these synthetic techniques have been effectively utilized for the fabrication of HEMs, they exhibit certain limitations, particularly in controlling material homogeneity and morphology. Consequently, optimizing these methods to enhance OER performance remains a significant challenge. Presently, research predominantly emphasizes the exploration of various preparation methods, with less attention given to a systematic review of how critical synthetic parameters, such as the choice of complexing agent, synthetic temperature, and calcination atmosphere to impact material properties. Specifically, different complexing agents have different complexing abilities for different metal ions, thus affecting the solubility and homogeneity of each metal component. And the type and amount of complexing agent will affect the microstructure of the material. For example, in the sol–gel method, the complexing agent can regulate the viscosity and stability of the sol, which in turn affects the gel formation and drying process. If the amount of complexing agent is too much, it may cause the sol to be too stable and difficult to form a homogeneous gel, while insufficient amount may lead to premature precipitation of metal ions and formation of inhomogeneous structure. The synthetic temperature is also a key parameter in the synthesis of HEMs, which directly affects the crystallinity, phase composition and microstructure of the materials. When the temperature is too low, it may lead to the incomplete formation of certain metal oxides. On the contrary, while the temperature is too high, it may lead to excessive sintering or phase transformation of certain metal oxides, thus changing the composition ratio and phase composition of the material. In addition, the calcination atmosphere has an effect on HEMs. For example, calcination in an inert atmosphere avoids the reaction between the material and external gases, thus preserving the original structure of the material. In contrast, calcination in an oxidizing atmosphere may lead to the formation of a dense oxide layer on the surface of the material, affecting the pore structure and specific surface area of the material. Therefore, by optimizing these synthetic conditions, the properties of HEMs can be effectively regulated, thus improving their catalytic efficiency in OER. This section aims to systematically review the effects of these key parameters on the OER properties of HEMs, focusing on the selection of complexing agents, the management of calcination temperature, and the adjustment of calcination atmosphere. 2.1 The complexing agent In the synthesis of HEMs, complexing agents are commonly utilized as chemical additives. These agents are a class of compounds capable of forming coordination compounds in chemistry, which are complexes formed by the bonding of a central metal ion with one or more ligands, typically organic molecules. The primary role of complexing agents is to regulate the solubility of metal raw materials, promote the uniform diffusion of metal ions and optimize the formation process of alloys. The morphology, crystal structure and elemental distribution of HEMs can be effectively controlled by selecting suitable complexing agents, thus significantly enhancing their OER catalytic performance. For example, many complexing agents contain functional groups such as carboxyl (COOH), hydroxyl (OH), and amino (NH2), which can coordinate with metal ions and modulate the electron cloud density of metal ions. This modulation of the electronic structure helps to optimize the adsorption and desorption ability of the materials to OER intermediates such as *OH, *O, and *OOH, thus lowering the reaction energy barriers and improving the OER performance. In this part, we will concentrate on presenting a variety of complexing agents, such as citric acid, glucose, urea, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC), glycine, and gallium metal, among others. 2.1.1 Citric acid Citric acid (C6H8O7), a prevalent organic acid and polyhydroxy acid, serves as a common complexing agent [36]. With three carboxyl groups (COOH) and one hydroxyl group (–OH), citric acid provides four lone pairs of electrons, enabling it to function as a quadridentate ligand [37]. The hydroxyl functional group within citric acid facilitates the formation of complexes with metal ions. This complexation process influences the solubility of the metal raw material. Through complexation reactions, citric acid enhances the solubility of metals, thereby aiding in the formation of a more uniform alloy precursor. In the preparation of electrocatalysts, citric acid is typically incorporated using methods such as solution impregnation, co-precipitation, co-deposition, and sol–gel techniques. Variations in the preparation methods can result in diverse adsorption morphologies and distributions of citric acid across the electrocatalyst surface, consequently influencing catalytic performance. This is due to the fact that citric acid as a complexing agent will form different adsorption configurations with the metal precursor through its COOH and OH groups, and this difference affects the spatial distribution of the metal ions, which leads to the formation of different material morphologies and pore structures after calcination. For instance, Miao et al. [38] utilized the sol–gel method to fabricate a (Ru0.2Ir0.2Cr0.2W0.2Cu0.2)O2 oxide by using citric acid, which is dissolved in NH3·H2O as a complexing agent to maintain the deionized water pH at 9, forming complexes with metal ions. The electrocatalyst possesses a rutile type structure (Fig. 3 a) and demonstrates a low overpotential of 220 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4 (Fig. 3b). However, unlike the above results, Zhang et al. [39] synthesized an electrocatalyst featuring Ag decorated septenary CoCuFeMoZnAgRu high entropy(oxy) hydroxide through a straightforward low-temperature electrochemical reconstruction process using citric acid as a complexing agent. In this instance, the citric acid complex undergoes a hydrolysis reaction with hydroxide ions (OH−), resulting in the creation of metal (oxygen) hydroxides. This resulting sample has a dense nanosheet structure (Fig. 3c), with a low overpotential of 298 mV at 100 mA cm−2 (Fig. 3d). This is due to the introduction of abundant oxygen vacancies by Ag and Ru ions, while the presence of Ag nanoparticles also improves the d-band filling energy level of Co, thus enhancing the OER performance. However, even when employing the same preparation method, the morphology and performance of the catalyst can vary due to different synthetic conditions. As an example, Ji and colleagues [40] employed a straightforward sol–gel method to synthesize a series of La1− x Ca x B2Co (x = 0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4) high entropy perovskite oxides. In this procedure, citric acid serves as a complexing agent, enabling the effective complexation of transition metal elements with rare earth metal elements. This process ensures that the transition metals and rare earth metals form a uniform solid solution during the subsequent calcination process. However, for all the ingredients, the powder exhibits a similar morphology, with nanoparticles measuring around 50 nm in size that tend to aggregate to into clusters (Fig. 3e, f). Notably, a minimum overpotential of 340 mV at 10 mA cm−2 is achieved at x = 0.4. Citric acid has various important roles in the preparation of HEMs. Firstly, citric acid can form stable complexes with metal ions, thus regulating the solubility and diffusion rate of metal ions. This property helps to realize the uniform distribution of metal ions during the synthetic process, thus forming precursors with uniform composition. In addition, citric acid could form a porous structure through decomposition, which significantly increases the specific surface area of the HEMs, providing more active sites for the OER. At the same time, the complexation between citric acid and metal ions significantly modulates the electronic structure of the catalytic centers. The carboxyl (COOH) and hydroxyl (OH) groups alter the electron density around the metal ions. This ligand field effect can shift the d-band center position (ε d) of the transition metals. An upward shift in ε d typically strengthens the adsorption of oxygenated intermediates (e.g., *OH, *O, *OOH) by enhancing orbital overlap between the metal d-states and the adsorbate orbitals [38,41]. Conversely, a downward shift weakens adsorption. Citric acid, by forming stable chelates, often leads to a tailored ε d that optimizes the binding energies of these key intermediates, thereby reducing the overall OER overpotential. This electronic modulation, coupled with the morphological control, underpins the enhanced OER kinetics observed in citric acid-assisted HEMs. Notably, these changes are achieved by modulating the composition and structure of the material, which in turn directly affects the OER performance. However, in the electrocatalyst preparation process, variations in the methods and conditions can lead to distinct reaction mechanisms involving citric acid. For example, under alkaline conditions, deprotonation of the citric acid carboxyl group enhances coordination with metal ions (Ru, Ir, etc.) and inhibits the precipitation of metal hydroxides, which promotes the formation of oxide phases. In addition, during high-temperature calcination, citric acid decomposition produces CO2 and H2O, forming a porous structure and increasing the specific surface area. However, the citric acid derived carbon residue may cover the active sites, thus the calcination temperature needs to be optimized to balance carbon removal and structural stability. As a result, the formation of oxides or hydroxides can produce diverse morphologies due to the adsorption and distribution of citric acid on the catalyst surface, which influences the properties in the electrocatalysts. This unpredictability process makes it challenging to precisely control the performance of the catalysts. Additionally, the specific mechanisms behind these effects have not yet been fully elucidated. At the same time, the synergistic effects of citric acid with other complexing agents or surfactants should be investigated to optimize the catalyst structure. By optimizing these parameters (e.g., citric acid concentration, pH, calcination temperature, calcination time, and the synergistic effects with other complexing agents or surfactants, etc.), the performance of the catalysts can be substantially enhanced, which ultimately translates to increased efficiency and selectivity across a broad spectrum of chemical reactions. 2.1.2 Glucose Besides citric acid, polyhydroxy compounds have the capability to complex metal ions, which include a variety of types and are available in large quantities. Glucose, a representative polyhydroxy carbohydrate, offers advantages like widespread availability and lower cost compared to citric acid. The hydroxyl groups in glucose can chelate, forming bonds with metal ions. This coordination results in the creation of metal glucose complexes, which in turn affect the metal's activity and chemical properties. For instance, He et al. [42] prepared a CrMnFeCoNi HEA via a cryogenic solution-based method at 260 °C. In this process, OAm served dual roles as a solvent and reducing agent, glucose acted as complexing agent and supplementary reducing agent, and CTAC was used as a surfactant (Fig. 4 a). The CrMnFeCoNi particles obtained an average dimension of 170 nm and an octahedral shape (Fig. 4b), with a high concentration of defects such as lattice distortions and dislocations. These characteristics result in an overpotential of 265 mV at 10 mA cm−2, a value that is lower than RuO2 (293 mV). DFT calculations show that Cr doping in the quaternary MnFeCoNi and defective HEA structures reduces the energy barriers for the generation of *OOH from *O and the release of O2, respectively, which are identified as the RDS of the OER process (Fig. 4c). In addition, Lai et al. [43] prepared a kind of HEOs with the morphological and structural change form solid spheres to core–shell spheres, and then to hollow spheres by using glucose as a complexing agent combined with calcination oxidation (Fig. 4d). Their TEM images and the corresponding element EDS mappings are shown in Fig. 4e–h. In the reaction process, glucose functions both as a carbon source for forming amorphous carbon spheres and as a strong complexing agent. Its numerous OH groups adsorb various metal ions into the carbon spheres. Subsequently, the metal-containing spherical carbon precursors are converted into crystalline HEOs via high-temperature calcination in air. This research provides an economical and efficient route for synthesizing high entropy compounds and highlights the great potential of HEOs catalysts in water electrolysis. Hence, the utilization of glucose as a complexing agent contributes to the control of morphology and structure during catalyst synthesis. Due to the presence of multiple hydroxyl functional groups in glucose molecules, these groups can form complexes with metal ions and also act as reducing agents, which can influence the regulation of the morphology of high entropy electrocatalysts. This is due to the fact that the hydroxyl group (OH) in glucose provides lone pairs of electrons to the free orbitals of the metal cations, and this coordination reduces the effective positive charge of the metal centers, decreasing the electrostatic repulsion between the ions, and promoting homogeneous mixing. This dual role allows glucose to effectively regulate the distribution of metal ions during synthesis, which in turn affects the morphology and structure of high-entropy electrocatalysts. During the subsequent heat treatment, glucose may decompose into a carbon matrix, which not only promotes the homogeneous dispersion of metal particles, but also forms a porous structure that significantly increases the specific surface area of the material, thus providing more active sites for OER. In addition, the reducing atmosphere generated by glucose pyrolysis can induce oxygen vacancies, which can enhance conductivity and promote *OOH formation by stabilizing O2 − intermediates and can further enhance the intrinsic activity, but excessive reduction leading to metal agglomeration needs to be avoided. The further research is needed to understand its mechanism of action under different synthetic conditions, as well as how to optimize its dosage and reaction conditions to achieve more efficient catalyst synthetic. Additionally, exploring the synergistic effects of glucose with other complexing agents or surfactants will provide new insights for developing novel and high-performance catalysts. 2.1.3 Urea Urea is an organic compound that contains one carbonyl group (CO) and two amino groups (NH2) as functional groups. It is commonly used as a fertilizer and a chemical feedstock. The amino and carbonyl functional groups in urea can coordinate with metal ions. In particular, the nitrogen within the amino group and the oxygen within the carbonyl group act as strong ligands, which can form coordination bonds with metals. This coordination is the basis for urea's role as a complexing agent, allowing metal ions to bind with urea and thereby altering the activity and chemical properties of the metal. For instance, Feng et al. [44] employed a hydrothermal method followed by sulfurization to fabricate porous nanosheets of high entropy (NiFeCoV)S2 on a nickel foam substrate (Fig. 5 a) using urea as an additive. During this process, urea not only acts as a complexing agent to combine with metal ions, but also provides an alkaline environment to regulate the formation of a two-dimensional lamellar structure. Due to the loose porous structure of the nanosheets, which provides abundant active sites, combined with the inherent high electrical conductivity of the metal sulfide and the strong synergistic effect among the four metal elements, (NiFeCoV)S2 has excellent OER performance, achieving an overpotential of 220 mV at 100 mA cm−2. In addition, Li et al. [45] utilized the hydrothermal method to synthesize novel high entropy layered double hydroxide (HELDH MC/NF nanosheet) microspheres, using urea as a complexing agent and providing an alkaline environment. As shown in Fig. 5b, numerous micron-sized spherical structures composed of thin sheets are observed, densely and uniformly packed together with rich porosity. The HELDH MC/NF nanosheet achieves a minimal overpotential of just 183 mV@10 mA cm−2. This efficiency stems from its capacity to precisely adjust the oxygen adsorption energy at the Fe and O sites on the basal plane (Fig. 5c, d). Incorporating non-active metal elements into the nanosheet increases both the structural disorder and the site polarization. This dual effect yields a unique catalytic performance that surpasses the capabilities of solely active elements. In addition to non-active element doping, single-atom doping can also effectively improve the catalytic performance of HEMs. Wang et al. [46] prepared a high entropy MnFeCoNiCu layered double hydroxide (AuSA-MnFeCoNiCu LDH) decorated with Au single atoms and O vacancies through hydrothermal and electrodeposition techniques (Fig. 5e), using urea as a metal ion complexing agent. The strong complexation between urea and precursor metal ions makes the elements uniformly distributed in the high entropy layered hydroxide nanosheets (Fig. 5f). It shows a low overpotential of 213 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Furthermore, AuSAMnFeCoNiCu LDH also has a high mass activity of 732.9 A g−1 at 250 mV overpotential in a 1.0 M KOH solution and shows excellent stability, maintaining performance for 700 h at approximately 100 mA cm−2. In summary, all the aforementioned preparation strategies are hydrothermal methods. Despite varying preparation conditions for each catalyst, the resulting samples consistently exhibit a nanosheet morphology. Urea can form complexes with metal ions, which facilitates the creation of lamellar structures during hydrothermal reactions. This phenomenon is primarily due to the coordination between urea molecules and metal ions, and this coordination behavior also alters the local electronic environment of the metal ions, leading to a shift in their d-orbital energy levels, which in turn optimizes the adsorption energy of the material for OER intermediates. For example, the coordination of urea with transition metals reduces the electron cloud density of the metal centers and enhances their interaction with the reaction intermediates, thereby enhancing the intrinsic catalytic activity. Although the role of urea in the formation of layered structures has been observed, its specific coordination mechanism and kinetic processes have not yet been fully elucidated. While the nanosheet morphology possesses a high specific surface area and abundant active sites, its performance in specific applications may be limited by the single morphology. For example, in some catalytic reactions, nanosheets may experience reduced activity due to stacking or aggregation. In future research, the opportunity exists to fine tune reaction parameters such as urea concentration and temperature to achieve urea guided catalyst formation with lamellar structures. This study is crucial for advancing the development of catalysts with customized shapes and characteristics, making them appropriate for various applications. 2.1.4 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC)/1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC) MOF (metal–organic framework) is an incredibly versatile, superporous nanomaterials composed of metal ions coordinated with organic ligands. These materials serve as a range of precursor materials are used to prepare HEMs. Thereinto, the organic ligands could form stable complexes with various metal ions to ensure the preparation of a single solid solution phase. As examples, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (BTC) are commonly used organic ligand. BDC possesses strong complexing capabilities due to the its two bridging groups, which offer various connection modes with metal central ions, providing a variety of building units. BDC can act as both a hydrogen bond donor and a hydrogen bond acceptor. This versatility makes it an outstanding ligand for supramolecular network structures. These characteristics make it an excellent ligand for the formation of metal–organic coordination polymers and have unique properties. For instance, Fereja et al. [47] successfully synthesized (FeNiCoCrCu)3O4 HEO by employing MOF as a sacrificial template using BDC as a ligand. BDC could produce strong complexation with metal ions, ensuring even distribution of metal ions within the MOF framework. Moreover, the MOF template effectively inhibited the aggregation of small precursor nanoparticles during the heating process to produce HEOs. This synthetic strategy ensures the formation of oxygen-rich, nanostructured HEOs with abundant surface area and numerous exposed active sites. Consequently, the synthesized HEO exhibits excellent electrocatalytic activity towards the OER. In addition, Wang et al. [48] synthesized (CoNiCuMnAl)/C HEA nanoparticles from the polymetallic MOF with BDC as ligands followed by pyrolysis (Fig. 6 a). The resulting HEA nanoparticles feature a novel core–shell structure, with a face-centered cubic HEA core enclosed within an extremely thin carbon layer. This structure outperforms the benchmark RuO2 catalyst, achieving a low overpotential of 215 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Beyond this point, BTC is also a common ligand with a five-membered heterocyclic structure containing a nitrogen atom with lone pairs of electrons, enabling it to establish coordination bonds with metal ions. Miao and colleagues [49] have prepared hollow-structured, polyhedron-shaped ZnFeNiCuCoRuO catalyst using a MOFs template strategy and BTC ligands via an ion-exchange method. The BTC ligand combines with metal ions to form the polyhedron structure, and its stronger coordination makes it easier for metal ions within the MOF derived framework (Fig. 6b–d). The resulting ZnFeNiCuCoRuO catalyst produced shows outstanding performance and remarkable stability for the OER across the entire pH range. It has a low overpotential of 170 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Additionally, it shows minimal activity loss, with only a 7 % decline over 30 h in alkaline conditions, and respective losses of 12 % and 8 % in acidic and neutral environments. In conclusion, the BDC and BTC ligands could combine with metal ions to form MOFs, which are formed by a pyrolysis process or ion exchange process to realize HEMs. The strong coordination bonds formed between metal ions and these ligands promote the creation of a single-phase solid solution in the resulting HEMs, while retaining the framework and pore structure of the MOF, which is more conducive to enhancing catalytic reaction activity. These attributes render it a highly promising candidate for diverse applications across multiple fields. Despite the significant advantages of BDC and BTC ligands in MOF synthesis, the stability of MOFs is a key issue, especially under complex reaction conditions or at high temperatures, where some MOF structures may undergo decomposition or degradation, thereby affecting their performance. In future research, the structure and stability of MOFs can be optimized by fine-tuning the synthetic parameters (such as ligand concentration, reaction temperature and time), thereby enhancing their durability in practical applications. 2.1.5 Glycine Glycine, also known as glycolic acid, is classified as a non-essential amino acid. It is considered the simplest amino acid, consisting of an amino group (NH2), a carboxyl group (COOH), and a methyl group (CH2 ). The presence of both acidic and alkaline functional groups allows glycine to ionize in water, adopting different molecular forms depending on the pH level of the solution. The carboxyl and amino groups in glycine have a tendency to coordinate with metal ions, leading to the formation of stable complexes. This property makes glycine a widely used complexing agent. For instance, Jiseok et al. [50] employed glycine as a complexing agent to fabricate ZnNiCoIrMn high-entropy alloy (HEA) via a sol–gel method. After drying the nitrate-based sol, a metal-glycine complex formed, which was subsequently reduced in an Ar/H2 atmosphere to yield a single-phase alloy (Fig. 7 a). Owing to its strong ligand effect, glycine facilitated the homogeneous complexation of Ni, Co, Ir, Mn, and Zn. Notably, Zn acted as a sacrificial component, enabling the formation of a nanoporous structure. The resulting ZnNiCoIrMn HEA demonstrated exceptional electrocatalytic performance, achieving overpotentials of merely 50 mV for the HER at 50 mA cm−2 and 237 mV for the OER at 10 mA cm−2 in a 0.1 M HClO4 solution. Besides, Rowan and co-workers [51] utilized glycine as a complexing agent in the synthesis of (Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2Cu0.2Zn0.2)Al2O4 (A5Al2O4) through a sol–gel method, followed by high temperature pyrolysis. The resulting A5Al2O4 has a band gap that is 0.9 eV narrower than those of the constituent spinel oxides. The strong complexation ability of glycine ensures the formation of pure crystalline phases of A5Al2O4, as depicted in Fig. 7b. A5Al2O4 achieves an overpotential of 400 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in an alkaline medium, surpassing the performance of each individual single metal counterpart at 1.7 V relative to the reversible hydrogen electrode (Fig. 7c). Glycine acts as a multifunctional complexing agent, and its bifunctional groups (NH2 and COOH) can realize the stable coordination of polymetallic ions through the formation of chelates, while the reducing gases generated by thermal decomposition can promote the low-temperature solid-phase reaction. In addition, glycine can construct hierarchical porous structures, which can improve the electrocatalytic activity. In summary, the selection of a complexing agent is crucial for considering the morphology and performance of catalysts. The choice and use of various complexing agents significantly influence both aspects. During the catalyst preparation process, factors such as the type and concentration of the complexing agents used are vital in determining the final product's morphology and properties. Certain complexing agents not only promote specific catalyst morphologies but also modulate surface chemistry, thereby affecting interactions between the catalyst and reactants. This, in turn, enables precise tuning of the catalyst's performance. In conclusion, the careful selection and accurate control of complexing agents are essential for obtaining catalysts with the desired morphology and superior performance. A thorough understanding of the interaction mechanisms between the complexing agents and the catalysts is key to their precise design and optimization, ensuring efficient conversions in a wide range of catalytic processes. 2.1.6 Gallium metal Gallium, a liquid metal at room temperature, exhibits a negative mixing enthalpy when combined with various other metallic components, making it an optimal base for creating alloys. Consequently, these liquid metals can be engineered to serve as a superior medium for crafting intricate, multi component alloys. Such alloys are anticipated to blend a wide range of metal elements uniformly under conditions that are highly forgiving. For example, Cao et al. [52] have pioneered a novel technique for the preparation of HEA NPs incorporating a diverse array of metallic constituents under moderate environmental conditions. This process leverages a liquid metal, such as gallium, as a reactive medium (Fig. 8 a). The nanoscale dispersion of gallium acts as a mixing vessel for a variety of metal salts, which serve as the initial materials. Subsequently, the salts undergo thermal decomposition and hydrogen reduction, leading to the amalgamation of the metal elements into the liquid metal matrix. This sequence of reactions ultimately yields HEA NPs at a temperature of 923 K. The HEA NPs, which can incorporate an extensive range of up to 11 distinct elements, including Cu, Pd, Ni, Mn, Al, In, Ga, Rh, Pt, Co and Mg, have been successfully manufactured. The EDS mapping confirms that these constituent elements are uniformly distributed within the nanoparticles (Fig. 8b). Fig. 8c illustrates the process of converting liquid metal nanoparticles coated with metal salts into alloy nanoparticles. During the heating process from room temperature to 923 K, liquid gallium gradually fuses with the metal salt. When the mixture is held at 923 K for a certain period, the liquid gallium and metal salt begin to separate. However, if the holding time is extended, they start to fuse again, eventually resulting in the creation of a new crystalline phase of HEA. Moreover, Lalita et al. [53] utilized readily scalable casting and comminution technique to produce a nanocrystalline Co-Fe-Ga-Ni-Zn (CFGNZ) electrocatalyst (Fig. 8d). Gallium metal acted as a facilitator, blending seamlessly with various other metals. The resulting HEAs demonstrate a significant reduction in overpotential, reaching 370 mV at 10 mA cm−2, and exhibit a Tafel slope of 71 mV dec−1. Furthermore, these alloys display exceptional endurance, maintaining performance through 6000 cycles and showing no degradation in OER activity over a period of 10 h. To sum up, the modest mixing enthalpy between gallium and a majority of metal elements helps to the decrease of Gibbs free energy. This characteristic enables the liquid gallium assisted method to create uniformly mixed alloys, effectively preventing the separation of elements, thereby addressing the challenge of immiscibility commonly encountered in alloy systems. Complexing agents synergistically enhance the OER activity and stability of HEMs through compositional homogenization, electronic modulation, and structure engineering. Specifically, complexing agents provide more synergistic active sites by stabilizing metal ions through ligand action and promoting uniform distribution of multiple elements to form a single solid solution phase. Complexing agents contain complexing groups, such as COOH, OH, NH2, etc., which can regulate the position of d-band centers, optimize the adsorption energies of intermediates (*OH, *OOH), and lower the reaction energy barriers. In addition, thermal decomposition of complexing agents may introduce oxygen vacancies or carbon residues (e.g., citric acid-derived carbon layers), and these defects can serve as active sites or electron transport channels. Through the above mechanisms, complexing agents not only optimize the compositional homogeneity and electronic structure of the materials, but also significantly enhance the OER activity and stability through structure engineering and defect engineering. Future studies can further explore the synergistic effects of complexing agents and in situ characterization techniques to precisely reveal the conformational relationship between coordination chemistry and catalytic performance, and provide guidance for the rational design of high-efficiency HEMs catalysts. 2.2 The synthetic temperature The synthetic temperature is pivotal among various preparation methods for HEMs, directly affects the compositional distribution, crystal structure, and electronic structure of the electrocatalysts, and thus significantly influences the catalytic properties. Varied synthetic temperatures can induce distinct phase transitions and alterations in crystal structure, thereby impacting both the microstructural features and the bulk properties of the materials. Fundamentally, the synthetic temperature governs atomic diffusion kinetics, phase stability, and defect formation, all of which profoundly shape the electronic environment of the active sites. Initially, high temperature synthesis (e.g., 1300–3000 °C) facilitates the diffusion and reaction among raw materials, encouraging the development of a more homogeneous alloy structure that holds greater potential for applications. The high configurational entropy at high synthetic temperature promotes the formation of single-phase solid solutions. However, excessively high temperature can also lead to elemental segregation or volatilization, disrupting the desired homogeneous electronic structure. Rapid quenching techniques (e.g., carbothermal shock) are often employed to kinetically trap the high-entropy state achieved at high temperature, preserving a homogeneous distribution of elements and the associated synergistic electronic effects (e.g., modulated d-band center positions, optimized charge transfer between constituent elements). Nevertheless, it is crucial to recognize that an excessively high synthetic temperature could complicate the control of the morphology and structure, and the required conditions are harsh. Therefore, developing medium temperature synthesis (e.g., 500–1300 °C) and low temperature synthesis (e.g., 100–500 °C) conditions are of great significance, as they can effectively reduce energy consumption and help maintain the stability of the material's microstructure. Medium temperature synthesis is the most commonly used temperature range in research, balancing energy consumption with material properties. In this range, the crystallinity and phase composition of the materials can be precisely regulated by temperature while avoiding the adverse effects of high temperatures. For example, HEMs synthesized at medium temperature typically have high crystallinity and uniform elemental distribution, thus optimizing their catalytic activity and stability. However, achieving complete elemental homogenization at medium temperature can be challenging. Incomplete diffusion might result in local compositional fluctuations, leading to variations in the local electronic structure across the material. Low temperature synthesis pays more attention to energy saving and fine tuning of microstructure. The lower diffusion rate of atoms at low temperature facilitates the formation of nanostructures or amorphous materials, which usually have more defects and active sites and can significantly enhance catalytic performance. Low temperature synthesis reduces elemental segregation and maintains the high-entropy properties of the materials. Besides, normal temperature synthesis (e.g., laser scanning ablation) provides a new pathway for the preparation of HEMs, which enables the homogeneous mixing of multiple elements and the modulation of efficient catalytic properties under mild conditions. As shown in Fig. 9 , the variations in calcination temperature and the corresponding preparation methods for different temperatures are illustrated. Notably, meticulous control over the calcination temperature is the key to achieving excellent OER performance. By optimizing the calcination temperature, the crystal structure, elemental distribution and surface chemistry of HEMs can be regulated, leading to the development of highly efficient and stable OER catalysts. 2.2.1 High temperature synthesis Currently reported ultra-fast high-temperature synthetic methods for HEMs are primarily based on the Joule heating principle, which originates from electromagnetic physics and follows Joule's law (Q = I 2 Rt), where I is the current, R is the resistance of the substrate material, and t is the duration of electrification. This method achieves heating rates of up to 105 K s−1 and cooling rates of 104 K s−1, enabling rapid heating of precursors to 3000 °C within 1 s. Such ultrafast heating and cooling rates are unattainable with conventional heating methods, making this approach highly advantageous for synthesizing metastable HEMs. Joule heating technology can be primarily categorized into two principles: indirect heating and direct heating. Thereinto, the indirect heating involves the initial heating of resistive metals, which then transfer thermal energy to the precursor via radiation. However, this method exhibits relatively low thermal efficiency, similar to conventional heating modes. For the direct heating, on the other hand, utilizes resistive metals or graphite as the reactor, achieving contact heating through short, high-current pulses. This enables temperatures of several thousand Kelvin within milliseconds, coupled with a specially designed cooling circulation system for rapid quenching, thereby facilitating the formation of HEMs. The direct Joule heating can be further divided into two methods. (i) Flash Joule Heating (FJH), which employs capacitor-driven high-voltage discharge to energize the precursor. The sample is placed in a quartz or ceramic tube positioned between two electrodes and heated under atmospheric or vacuum conditions. FJH finds wide applications in graphene oxide synthesis, phase modulation, and metastable material generation. (ii) Carbon Thermal Shock (CTS), in which, the high current is applied to carbon materials to generate heat, leading to the formation of HEMs. The carbothermal shock (CTS) method is the most extensively utilized rapid high-temperature synthesis technique for producing HEMs. For example, Yao et al. [54] were the first to use the carbothermal shock method to produce a diverse array of HEA NPs. They achieved this by subjecting precursor metal salt mixtures, loaded onto carbon supports, to a thermal shock at 2000 K for 55 ms, with a heating rate of approximately 105 K s−1 (Fig. 10 a). These nanoparticles exhibit tailored compositions, sizes, and phases and are effectively integrated onto carbon nanofiber substrates. The exceptionally rapid heating and cooling rates of the method, coupled with surface defects and oxygen-enriched (O*) sites on the carbon nanofibers, facilitate swift “fission” and “fusion” of particles. This dynamic process leads to a homogeneous dispersion of a multi-element mixture (Fig. 10b). In addition, Ali et al. [55] described the in-situ production of non-noble metal HEO catalyst on carbon fibers using rapid Joule heating and quenching. They applied a current of 15 A in three pulses (each 500 ms in duration) to a gas diffusion layer electrode (GDL) coated with a metal precursor, subjecting it to rapid Joule heating. The resulting temperature reached a high range of approximately 1300 to 1700 °C (Fig. 10c). After 1.5 s, the carbon fiber GDL was successfully coated with HEA nanoparticles (Fig. 10d). The synthesized HEO nanoparticles exhibit diameters ranging between 20 and 80 nm, form an oxide phase (Fig. 10e), and show the lowest overpotential of 240 mV at 10 mA cm−2. In fact, beyond its application in CTS synthesis of HEMs, Joule heating technology can also rapidly convert carbon-based precursors into graphene via a carbothermal shock furnace, enabling ultrafast graphene production. Furthermore, this technique could achieve rapid phase transitions and synthesis through millisecond-scale Joule heating to yield metastable nanomaterials with tailored structures and properties. Moreover, the key physical parameters including sintering temperature, duration, and cooling rate are controllable during the Joule heating process, facilitating further tuning of the microstructure of HEMs. These technical advantages have opened new pathways for developing novel high-entropy electrocatalysts. 2.2.2 Medium temperature synthesis Except for ultra-high temperature synthetic like Joule fever, this section focuses on the component and characteristic of HEMs prepared at calcination temperatures spanning from 500 to 1300 °C. Controlling the temperature within this range allows for the adjustment of the microstructure and properties of these materials, which may affect their performance in hydrolysis catalysis and other related applications. For instance, Wang et al. [56] prepared large Cr x MnFeNi (x = 0.8, 1.0, 1.5) high entropy alloys using vacuum induction melting (VIM). The alloys were homogenized in an inert argon atmosphere at 1200 °C to enhance uniformity. Afterward, the alloy was hot forged into a rectangular billet at approximately 1150 °C, followed by annealing. This thorough preparation process ensures that the resulting HEAs are of high purity and homogeneity. The prepared HEAs exhibit excellent water electrolysis performance. To address the varying affinities between different metals and phosphorus in synthesizing phase pure high entropy phosphide (HEP), Ding et al. [57] emphasized the importance of uniformly distributing the elemental atoms in the precursor while maintaining comparable diffusion rates for each element (Fig. 11 a). They employed a hydrothermal method to create a metal–organic gel (MOG) containing Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, and Cd, along with phosphorus species. Subsequently, this MOG gel was subjected to calcination at 900 °C in a H2/Ar atmosphere within a tubular furnace. During calcination at 900 °C, the metal ions combined with phosphorus to create FeCoNiMnCdP in a reductive environment, and the organic components (TPPi and PVP) were converted into a carbon support through carbonization. Meanwhile, the simultaneous doping of C and N in high entropy nanoparticles greatly optimizes the cocktail effect of high entropy compounds. The resulting FeCoNiMnCdP demonstrated outstanding OER performance, with a lower overpotential of 250 mV at 10 mA cm−2. In another research effort, Wang et al. [58] successfully produced a FeCoNi-based HEO electrocatalyst containing Al and Ce, referred to as AlCeM3O, through calcination at 500 °C. They said that compared to M3O, the aluminum (Al) component has a lower standard electrode potential, making it more prone to selective dissolution under alkaline oxygen evolution reaction conditions. During the electrochemical activation process, the in situ removal of Al improves the electronic states of other metal centers. This action forms a highly accessible active surface that significantly boosts the synergistic effects of M3O. Meanwhile, cerium (Ce), which has a high MO bond energy, can effectively reinforce the MO framework effectively by modifying the band structure. As a result, AlCeM3O emerges as an extremely robust electrocatalyst with a highly stable structure (Fig. 11b). Because of these good points, it has a low overpotential of 303.7 mV at 500 mA cm−2. It can keep 95.8 % efficiency after working for 840 h. This represents the most outstanding performance ever reported for HEOs. In addition, we find that the synthetic temperature directly affects the morphological structure of HEOs. By optimizing the synthetic temperature, the precise regulation of the morphological structure of HEMs can be achieved. For example, our group [43] proposed a general amorphous-to-crystalline transformation route, which is the conversion of amorphous precursors into crystalline HEMOs by controlling the calcination temperatures (350, 500, and 650 °C). As the temperature increases, the structure of the HEMOs evolves from a solid sphere to a core–shell structure and then to hollow spheres. The different temperatures allow for a controlled diffusion rate of metal ions and oxygen, leading to the structural transformation. This phenomenon is attributed to the thermally induced non-uniform shrinkage process coupled with Kirkendall effect diffusion, where metal ions diffuse outward at different rates, leading to the formation of pores agglomerated at the nanometer level, characterized by the production of different nanostructure. Calcination temperatures between 500 and 1300 °C are commonly used by researchers. This is because within this temperature range, a wide variety of HEMs can be synthesized, such as high entropy alloy, high entropy metal phosphide, high entropy oxide and others. However, it is difficult to precisely control the microstructure of HEMs during this temperature range, the material may also be in a partially crystallized stage, where some of the metal salts may not be fully converted to oxides, resulting in phase segregation in the material. Therefore, researchers must explore lower temperatures to achieve fine regulation of the catalyst to obtain high activity and high entropy electrocatalysts. 2.2.3 Low temperature synthesis With the ongoing advancement in materials science, probing calcination temperatures in the medium to low range, between 100 and 500 °C, presents novel opportunities for the fabrication of HEMs. This avenue transcends the constraints associated with traditional high temperature synthesis and charts a new course towards achieving finer microstructures and enhanced performance [59]. The research endeavors in this domain are poised not only to offer a more economical pathway for the mass production of HEAs but also to foster the development of more adaptable and sustainable approaches for material design and engineering applications. As an example, Wytse et al. [60] documented the fabrication of nanosheets of high entropy spinel oxide ((CrFeCoNiMo)3O4), referred to as HEO–NS (Fig. 12 a), which were annealed at 400 °C for 2 h. In this process, graphene oxide (GO) served as a disposable template to shape the nanosheet and guarantee a high density of accessible active sites. TEM and EDS mappings reveal that the material retains its two-dimensional morphology, with all six elements evenly distributed throughout the layered framework (Fig. 12b, c). In addition, high valence Cr and Mo can modulate the electronic structure of high entropy spinel, weaken the MO bond and shift the reaction path toward LOM. This high entropy spinel exhibited an overpotential of 255.3 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Moreover, it demonstrated exceptional long-term stability. Sun and his colleagues [61] proposed a novel reduction diffusion technique for synthesizing a variety of Pt-based HEA nanowires, incorporating up to 10 elements (Fig. 12d). Unlike conventional high temperature preparation methods, this approach enables the homogeneous blending of multiple elements at lower temperatures (180–220 °C), resulting in the formation of high entropy nanowires with controllable structures and compositions. Notably, this method can be extended to fabricate 17 different types of high-entropy nanowires. Nguyen and his colleagues [62] presented a facile hydrothermal method for cultivating a high entropy layered double hydroxide (LDH) on the surface of nickel foam heated at 120 °C for 12 h. The resulting five-membered FeNiCoMnCr structure manifests a flower-like morphology composed of nanosheet paddles and has an overpotential of 218 mV at 50 mA cm−2. This is due to the modulation of the interactions between the polymetallic components along the electronic structure, which promotes the formation of highly active and highly valent γ-NiOOH species and greatly improves the electrocatalytic activity. Producing HEMs via calcination within the temperature range of 100–500 °C represents a cutting-edge area of contemporary research, attracting significant attention. Unlike conventional high-temperature synthetic techniques, medium-to-low temperature calcination can substantially reduce energy consumption, improve production efficiency, and promote environmental sustainability. Additionally, this approach enables finer control over the morphology and structure of HEMs. However, within this temperature range, the diffusion rates of elements are relatively low, which may lead to issues such as compositional inhomogeneity and phase separation. Furthermore, materials synthesized at low temperatures often exhibit lower crystallinity, adversely affecting their mechanical properties and thermal stability. Therefore, designing precursors with lower activation energy could promote uniform mixing of elements at medium and low temperatures. 2.2.4 Normal temperature synthesis Traditionally, the preparation of HEAs has often necessitated high-temperature and high-pressure environments, which consume more energy and limit industrial applications. Consequently, devising a method to synthesize HEMs at ambient temperatures holds immense importance. Wang et al. [63] presented a simple yet adaptable approach, known as laser scanning ablation, for synthesizing a wide range of HEA and ceramic nanoparticles. This technique uses laser pulses, each with a duration of just five nanoseconds, to vaporize nanoparticle precursors in an ambient environment. The ultrafast process enables the combination of various metallic elements, irrespective of their thermodynamic solubility. By concentrating energy within specific microregions, the laser scanning ablation approach effectively loads HEM nanoparticles onto different substrates. As displayed in Fig. 13 a, b, metal chlorides in equimolar proportions were initially applied to a substrate. This substrate was subsequently moved into hexane and exposed to laser pulses at ambient temperature, ultimately forming CNFs supported by AuFeCoCuCr NPs. The formation mechanism of HEA nanoparticles is illustrated in Fig. 13c. The laser pulse passes through the liquid alkane and reaches the substrate surface coated with precursors (Fig. 13c(i)). Owing to the strong optical field and the elevated transient temperature at the focal point, the precursors tend to melt or decompose upon exposure to the laser. A high-temperature, high-pressure jet, consisting of ions, atoms, clusters, and vapors, is formed at the interface between the substrate and the liquid (Fig. 13c(ii)). The existence of multiple elements in the plume drives the formation of solid solution phases, because of the substantial enthalpy change associated with mixing (TΔS mix). The recoil of the plume produces emission shockwaves, leading to ultrasonic expansion into the surrounding liquid (Fig. 13c(iii)). As the plume swiftly cools and transfers energy to the alkane (Fig. 13c(iii)), high entropy alloy nucleation takes place, which is then followed by the merging of crystal nuclei (Fig. 13c(iv)). Simultaneously, the energy triggers the creation of high-temperature, high-pressure bubbles that expand into the liquid. As these bubbles expand, the temperature and pressure inside them rapidly diminish and revert to their initial levels when the bubbles collapse (Fig. 13c(v)). This collapse releases a substantial quantity of energy, which facilitates the creation of HEA nanoparticles. Subsequent rapid cooling, propelled by swift heat transfer between the ablated region and the adjacent liquid, maintains the solid solution phase and prevents the emergence of intermetallic compounds. Interestingly, during the preparation of PtAuPdCuCrSn NPs, they found that the size of HEA NPs was different for pulse time under one laser pulse of the same power density with different laser interaction times. Among them, the longer the laser exposure time, the larger the size of the HEA NPs (Fig. 13d, e), which was mainly due to the different thermal diffusion lengths of substrates. As a result, the synthesized PtIrCuNiCr (Fig. 13d) nanoparticles exhibit an overpotential of 185 mV at 10 mA cm−2. This technique has also been applied to the synthesis of high entropy sulfide, high entropy phosphide, high entropy oxide, high entropy boride and high entropy nitride. This strategy significantly advances the HEM nanostructure library, achieving greater compositional diversity and structural complexity. In summary, the fabrication of these HEMs at room temperature and normal pressure has become an exciting direction in materials science. This innovative technique not only lowers energy consumption and production costs but also offers potential for a more sustainable manufacturing process. 2.3 The calcination atmosphere The calcination atmosphere of HEMs is a critical factor in their preparation process, significantly influencing the crystal structure, phase composition, and ultimate properties. The choice of calcination atmosphere, such as a hydrogen/argon mixture, air, argon, nitrogen, or ammonia, is crucial in shaping the elemental behavior and reaction dynamics, thereby fine-tuning the microstructure and properties of HEMs. For instance, in a hydrogen/argon (H2/Ar) mixture atmosphere, hydrogen exhibits strong reducing properties, facilitating the reduction of metal oxides to form high-entropy alloys (HEAs) and promoting homogeneous elemental distribution. In contrast, under an air atmosphere, metal precursors react with oxygen to yield high-entropy oxides (HEOs), which typically incorporate abundant oxygen vacancies and defective structures, thereby enhancing the material's catalytic activity. Alternatively, nitrogen (N2) or ammonia (NH3) atmospheres are often employed to synthesize high-entropy nitrides (HENs), where nitriding reactions modulate the material's electronic structure and surface chemistry. This section will delve into the application of various calcination atmospheres in the synthesis of HEMs and examine the distinct impacts these environments have on their properties. Critically, the calcination atmosphere profoundly influences the electronic structure, oxidation states, and defect chemistry of HEMs, which are fundamental determinants of their OER catalytic mechanism and activity. Through this analysis, the goal is to provide fresh insights and approaches for the study and practical application of HEMs in electrocatalytic OER. 2.3.1 Hydrogen and argon mixture atmosphere The use of a hydrogen/argon gas mixture in the fabrication of HEAs is a sophisticated technique in the processing of advanced metallic materials. During the melting and casting stages, argon acts as an inert shielding gas, creating a protective atmosphere that prevents oxidation and nitridation by inhibiting the interaction of alloy constituents with atmospheric oxygen and nitrogen at elevated temperatures. The addition of hydrogen further enhances the reduction of oxide formation, as hydrogen's strong reducing properties at high temperatures enable it to react with any oxides present, forming water vapor that is subsequently expelled. When the calcination atmosphere consists of a hydrogen/argon blend, this environment typically facilitates the synthesis of HEAs. For instance, Mei and his colleagues [64] developed a MOF-derivative approach by calcining the MOF precursor in a hydrogen/argon (5 % hydrogen and 95 % argon) atmosphere to synthesize carbon-supported FeCuNiMo high entropy alloy (FeCuNiMo HEA/C) through high temperature reduction (Fig. 14 a). In this process, the MOF precursor, when calcined in the hydrogen/argon mixture, undergoes a series of transformations where the high temperatures, combined with the reducing atmosphere provided by hydrogen, promote the diffusion and amalgamation of metal elements. This facilitates atomic exchange and the formation of chemical bonds among different metals, ultimately leading to the conversion of various metal ions into a uniform alloy. Consequently, the FeCuNiMo HEA/C exhibits an average particle size of 8 ± 0.3 nm and delivers an overpotential of 250 mV at 10 mA cm−2. In a word, in a hydrogen/argon mixed atmosphere, argon acts as a protective gas, while hydrogen serves a reducing role. This synergistic effect helps accelerate the preparation of HEAs. The strong reducing environment provided by hydrogen optimized the catalytic performance of HEMs in OER by changing its electronic structure. The reduction reduced the oxidation state of metal elements, increased the d-orbital electron density, and shifted the d-band center downward, which moderately weakened the adsorption strength of oxygen-containing intermediates (*OH, O, OOH) and crucial for improving the OER activity. In addition, the uniform elemental distribution under H2/Ar mixture atmosphere ensured a homogeneous electronic environment around the active site, which maximized the synergistic effect between different elements and thus enhanced the OER catalytic performance. 2.3.2 Nitrogen/argon atmosphere Apart from HEAs, high entropy metal compounds are also formed in pure argon or nitrogen atmosphere as protective gases, without hydrogen as a reducing atmosphere. In this case, high temperatures are often employed to facilitate the reaction, which aids in increasing the reaction rate and energy, rendering the feedstock more susceptible to chemical reactions. As an example, Zhang and his colleagues [65] prepared the NiFeCoMnOOH catalyst through surface reconstruction of the nanoporous NiFeCoMn precursor under an Ar atmosphere, resulting in an overpotential of 194 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Besides, Guan and co-workers [66] proposed an in situ modulation strategy to synthesize N-FeCoNiAlMoO x by introducing structure directing agents and electronic modulators under a nitrogen atmosphere (Fig. 14b). In this process, nitrogen acts as a protective gas to promote the combination of small molecules containing nitrogen and metal oxides to form nitrogen-doped HEOs. The introduction of nitrogen into HEOs refines the MO bond strength, modifies the electronic configuration, and stimulates lattice oxygen, which in turn boosts the inherent activity of the catalyst. Consequently, N-FeCoNiAlMoO x demonstrates exceptional OER performance, with overpotentials of 240 and 285 mV at 10 and 100 mA cm−2, respectively. Notably, its performance shows only a 1.25 % decline after a 100 h stability test at 10 mA cm−2, underscoring its outstanding durability and stability. To sum up, in protective gases such as nitrogen and argon, metal ions retain their original oxidation states. Thereinto, the diversity of synthetic conditions leads to the formation of various types of high-entropy metal compounds. 2.3.3 Air atmosphere When the precursor undergoes calcination in air without any special gas at high temperature, all organic molecules will be burned off, and the metal precursor would react with atmospheric oxygen to produce HEOs. During this process, the high temperature under air could enhance the mixing extent among distinct metal elements via thermodynamic driving forces, leading to the creation of complex oxides characterized by high entropy attributes. This distinctive synthetic approach endows HEOs with properties markedly distinct from those of traditional oxide materials, encompassing enhanced thermal stability, mechanical robustness, and electrochemical performance. As an example, Liao and colleagues [67] successfully produced HEO incorporating the elements Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni and O by means of resin templating and precise heat treatment under the air atmosphere, which could form stable crystals and abundant oxygen vacancies (Fig. 14c). The presence of a high degree of oxygen vacancies in HEOs-600 significantly impacts the active states of these metals, resulting in enhanced catalytic performance with an overpotential of 174 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Furthermore, Fereja et al. [47] employed a MOF as a sacrificial template to fabricate (FeNiCoCrCu)3O4 by calcining at 800 °C under an air atmosphere. The MOF template effectively inhibits the clustering of small precursor nanoparticles, yielding HEOs that possess abundant oxygen vacancies, an extensive surface area, and rich active sites. This HEO demonstrated excellent OER catalytic activity, achieving a low overpotential of 270 mV at 10 mA cm−2. In summary, HEOs are readily formed in an air atmosphere. Since the process is not restricted by specific atmospheric conditions, the resulting HEOs often exhibit stable structures and excellent thermal stability. Mixed valence states (e.g., Fe3+/Fe2+, Co3+/Co2+, Mn3+/Mn4+) arising from air oxidizable are a major feature of HEOs and key to their OER activity. The coexistence of different valence states promotes electron hopping between metal cations, thus improving the electronic conductivity. However, due to the complexity of air composition, impurity elements or defects may be introduced, potentially affecting the purity and performance consistency of the materials. In addition, the high entropy effect stabilizes oxygen vacancies within the oxide lattice under oxidizing conditions, which can act as an active center for hydrolysis dissociation, provides a pathway for proton transfer, and modulates the local electronic structure of neighboring metal cations, enhancing their intrinsic activity towards OER intermediates. In terms of future development, researchers could focus on developing more precise synthetic techniques to achieve control over the structure and properties of HEOs. 2.3.4 Ammonia atmosphere Unlike inert protective atmospheres, ammonia gas, as a functional gas, has high reactivity and readily reacts with metal ions at elevated temperatures to form high entropy nitrides (HENs). This is also a common method for synthesizing nitrides. For example, Zhu et al. [68] synthesized the Cu0.5Fe0.5NNi2Co0.5Fe0.5 thin films using a chemical solution deposition method, followed by annealing in an ammonia atmosphere (Fig. 14d). Ammonia gas, being highly reactive, has strong reducing properties at high temperatures, which can react with metal ions to form nitrides, thereby enabling the nitridation of HEAs. The resulting high entropy anti-perovskite nitride, an emerging category of transition metal nitrides, showed great potential for electrocatalysis in alkaline OER. It exhibited a low overpotential of 370 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and featured a minimal Tafel slope of 55 mV dec−1. It also maintained long-term stability. These attributes are likely due to its straightforward structure and outstanding electronic conductivity. The key electronic structure change induced by the ammonia gas atmosphere is the incorporation of nitrogen anions (N3−) into the crystal lattice to form HENs. Nitrogen has a higher electronegativity and a different ionic radius compared to oxygen, and thus can significantly alter the bonding and energy band structure. The hybridization of the N 2p orbitals with the metal d-orbitals is different from that of the O 2p orbitals. This hybridization often leads to narrower d-band widths and lower d-band centers than in the corresponding oxides. A lower d-band center weakens the adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates (*OH, O, OOH), thus potentially optimizing the binding energy of the OER. In addition, MN bond is typically more covalent than MO bond. Increased covalency promotes electron escape and thus increased conductivity, which is highly beneficial for electrocatalysis as it facilitates charge transfer. The calcination atmosphere has an important effect on the composition and electronic structure of HEMs, which in turn significantly modulates their catalytic properties. In a H2/Ar atmosphere, the strong reducing property of hydrogen promotes the reduction of metal oxides to HEAs, while the inert argon prevents oxidation, contributes to the uniform distribution of elements and optimizes the electronic structure. In inert atmospheres such as N2 or Ar, materials tend to form high-entropy metal compounds, and the introduction of nitrogen regulates the electronic conductivity of the material, while the inert atmosphere preserves the original porous structure of the material. In air atmosphere, the metal precursors react with oxygen to form HEOs, whose abundant oxygen vacancies and defect structures can provide more active sites and enhance the catalytic activity. While in NH3 atmosphere, the high reactivity of ammonia prompts the metal to combine with nitrogen to form HENs, which optimizes the electronic structure and surface chemistry of the material through the electronic modulation of nitrogen atoms. By precisely modulating the calcination atmosphere, the directional design of the composition, electronic structure and surface properties of the materials can be realized, thus significantly enhancing their catalytic activity and stability in the OER. In summary, the preparation of high entropy OER electrocatalyst is influenced by the choice of complexing agent, synthetic temperature, and calcination atmosphere. The components, structure, and properties of high entropy OER electrocatalyst can be adjusted through the careful selection of complexing agent, calcination methods, and calcination atmosphere, leading to the attainment of exceptional OER catalytic activity. The related methods and characteristics are compiled in Table S3 (Supporting Information). Additionally, future studies could achieve precise active-site design by optimizing the combination of complexing agents and calcination conditions. For instance, using glucose with low-temperature calcination to synergistically control nanosheet morphology, or employing BDC/BTC ligands coupled with an inert atmosphere to preserve the porous structure of MOF templates. Furthermore, the interplay between different atmospheres (e.g., H2/Ar reducing atmosphere) and temperatures (e.g., low temperature to suppress elemental segregation vs. high temperature to enhance solid-solution formation) could be systematically investigated to tailor the electronic structure and defect density of materials. Finally, dynamic atmosphere modulation (e.g., alternating oxidizing/reducing atmospheres during calcination) may further improve the homogeneity and catalytic performance of HEMs. The synergistic optimization of complexing agent, calcination temperature, and atmosphere holds great promise for overcoming current synthetic limitations and opening new avenues for the rational design of highly efficient OER catalysts. 3 The influence of composition of high entropy materials on OER performance The capacity to design the composition and architecture of HEMs can effectively modulate electronic structure, defects, interface structure, element synergistic effects, and more. This, in turn, endows the materials with different electrocatalytic OER performance. Compared to traditional doped catalysts, which often rely on a single or a few dopants to enhance catalytic activity, HEMs offer a significant advantage due to their multi-elemental nature. The diverse elemental composition of HEMs allows for a broader range of electronic structures and active sites, leading to enhanced catalytic performance. Up to now, HEMs have been divided into two main categories: high entropy alloys and high entropy compounds. High entropy alloys usually consist of five or more metal elements, whereas high entropy compounds incorporate both metal and non-metallic elements. With increasing attention from researchers, high entropy compounds featuring diverse non-metallic elements have demonstrated high performance in various fields. Examples including high entropy oxides (HEOs), high entropy layered hydroxide (HELHs), high entropy sulfides (HESs), high entropy phosphides (HEPs), high entropy carbides (HECs), high entropy nitrides (HENs), high entropy borides (HEBs), and other similar materials are depicted in Fig. 15 . This section will concentrate on elucidating the influence of composition of HEMs on OER performance. 3.1 High entropy alloys High entropy alloys (HEAs) are characterized by the inclusion of five or more metallic elements, each contributing an atomic fraction ranging from 5 to 35 %. Another definition describes HEAs as alloys formed by five or more elements in an equiatomic or near equiatomic ratio, where their mixing entropy exceeds the melting entropy of the alloy, resulting in the formation of a high entropy solid solution phase [69,70]. The design flexibility of their composition and structure, combined with their excellent catalytic activity and stability in electrolytes, makes HEAs particularly well-suited for catalyzing the OER in water electrolysis, garnering significant attention. Zhu et al.
