[71] synthesized a single-phase face-centered cubic (fcc) FeCoNiCuMn HEA by integrating Fe, Co, and Ni with Mn, which has low electronegativity, and Cu, which has high electronegativity, using a polymer fiber nanoreactor method (Fig. 16 a). The resulting FeCoNiCuMn HEA/CNF composite material features a randomly dispersed three-dimensional (3D) network of nanofibers, with the small HEA NPs of 12.9 nm in size uniformly distributed throughout the CNFs. The in situ Raman spectra of FeCoNiCuMn HEA/CNF yielded a Raman peak at 602 cm−1 attributed to the bending mode of free CuOH. The appearance of a small peak at 1066 cm−1 is attributed to the OO stretching vibration of the superoxide species (O2 −) bonded to the Cu site in FeCoNiCuMn HEA/CNF. The weaker intensity of the CuOH peak and the enhanced intensity of the peak of the superoxide species at higher potentials confirm the occurrence of the OER on the Cu site in FeCoNiCuMn HEA/CNF. In addition, no Raman peaks of other metal sites were observed in the in situ Raman spectra, indicating that the Cu site in HEA is the active site for OER (Fig. 16b). During this formation of HEAs process, strong local electronic interactions, driven by differences in electronegativity, cause the inert Cu to migrate to electron rich active sites, thereby effectively lowering the adsorption energy of reactants. This, in turn, enhances the activity of the OER. Remarkably, this FeCoNiCuMn HEA/CNF demonstrates excellent activity, displaying an overpotential of 386 mV at 200 mA cm−2. Although FeCoNiCuMn HEA/CNF showed some activity in OER catalysis, the active site of the material was highly dependent on Cu, while the other metals (Fe, Co, Ni, Mn) did not show significant catalytic activity. This single active site dependence may limit the overall performance of the catalyst. Apart from single phase HEA particles, the performance of HEA as an OER catalyst can be significantly enhanced by structural reconfiguration that facilitates the optimization of the electronic structure of the material and the generation of additional active sites. For example, Huang and colleagues [72] prepared FeCoNiRu-450 HEA electrocatalysts using high-entropy metal–organic skeletons (HEMOFs) as precursors (Fig. 16c), which had an overpotential of 243 mV at 10 mA cm−2, and remained constant at 10 mA cm−2 even after 40 h (Fig. 16d). Interestingly, a spinel oxide layer appeared on the surface of the HEA after 40 h of stability testing and the distance between the edge of the particles and the left surface, which is the oxide surface, was estimated and measured to be about 10 nm (Fig. 16e). It is the emergence of the self-reconfiguration process on the surface of the FeCoNiRu-450 that gives it a sustainable OER stability over time. And the Nitet-Ruoct-Cooct hollow site presents the lowest OH− adsorption free energy (ΔG 1) and O2 desorption free energy (ΔG 4), suggesting that this hollow site exhibits the best electrocatalytic OER performance (Fig. 16f). In addition to surface structural remodeling, the appearance of amorphous phases is also an important phenomenon. Zhou et al. [73] successfully prepared FeCoNiCrMo1.0 HEA nanoparticles with an amorphous structure by the strategy of inert gas condensation (IGC) with picosecond laser source of HEA nanofibers (Fig. 16g). It is obvious that the content of Mo element is from more to less, and the increase of Mo element exacerbates the lattice distortion (Fig. 16h). When the atomic arrangement cannot maintain the critical point of the lattice array, the lattice array is destroyed, resulting in the formation of an amorphous structure. By changing the content of Mo in HEAs, the “cocktail effect” can be maximized to regulate the electron distribution and structural disorder of FeCoNiCrMo x . As a result, FeCoNiCrMo1.0 exhibits excellent OER catalytic performance with an overpotential of 294.5 mV at 100 mA cm−2 (Fig. 16i). However, this study did not explore in detail the specific role of each metal element in the catalytic process, especially how the introduction of Mo affects the electronic structure and catalytic activity of other metal elements, which may lead to an incomplete understanding of the mechanism of catalyst performance enhancement. In addition to the above methods, the dealloying as a very effective fabrication method for high-entropy nanoporous structure has been investigated. The dealloying method is used to form nanoporous structures with high specific surface area and abundant active sites by selectively dissolving one or several elements in the alloy, which can significantly enhance the OER performance of the materials. For example, Yu et al. [74] synthesized free-standing porous HEAs consisting of 12 or 16 different elements, including both noble and non-noble metals by a dealloying method. This synergistic elemental combination of HEAs with fine porous structures resulted in a catalytic activity superior to that of commercial IrO2 catalysts in the OER. Based on an extensive study of multi-component HEAs, Qiu et al. [75] prepared nanoporous HEAs covered with high-entropy (oxygen) hydroxides (HEOs) by combining precursor alloy design with chemical etching to controllably combine five or more nonprecious metals. The results show that the alloy composition plays a dominant role in enhancing the OER activity, with the np-AlNiCoFeX (X = Mo, Nb, Cr) combination exhibiting the highest activity. And the overpotential of AlNiCoFeMo is only 240 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. They also found that when the alloy components were increased to five or more, such as quinary AlNiCoFeMo and AlNiCoFeCu as well as senary AlNiCoFeCuMo, they exhibited greatly enhanced electrochemical durability even after 2000 cycles. The addition of Cu and Mo, which have different physicochemical properties in terms of melting point, crystal structure, electronegativity, and redox potential, can further improve the electrochemical durability of quaternary np-AlNiCoFe alloys. This is due to the high entropy effect of the quinary and senary alloys, which plays a major role in improving the electrochemical durability. HEAs served as water electrolysis catalysts, exhibiting outstanding catalytic activity owing to their remarkable resistance and stability. By introducing specific active sites or special structures on the surface of HEAs, the reaction rate and efficiency can be improved, and the OER can be promoted. However, with further research, it has been found that a complex oxide or hydroxide layer tends to form on the surface of HEAs in high-temperature oxidizing environments or electrochemical applications. This phenomenon not only reveals the dynamic behavior of HEAs during oxidation or hydrolysis but also provides important insights into the design and development of HEOs and HEHs. 3.2 High entropy oxides/layered hydroxide Traditional transition metal oxides and hydroxides are viewed as promising OER electrocatalysts, thanks to their affordability, abundant reserves, and inherent high activity. Nevertheless, their poor conductivity and mass transport capabilities hinder their practical applications. In contrast, high-entropy metal oxides and hydroxides have garnered interest because of their distinctive electronic effects and the beneficial interactions among multiple elements [49]. The introduction of oxygen in HEAs not only promotes the formation of HEOs, but also significantly enhances the OER properties of the material through various mechanisms. Oxygen atoms have a high electronegativity and are able to attract electrons, thus changing the electron cloud density of the surrounding metal atoms. This change in electronic structure optimizes the adsorption and desorption of OER intermediates such as *OH, *O and *OOH from the active sites on the surface of the material. For example, in HEOs, doping of oxygen atoms can improve OER activity by modulating the position of the d-band center of metal atoms and lowering the adsorption energy barriers of reaction intermediates. In addition, doping of oxygen atoms, whose dimensions are different from those of metal atoms, leads to distortion of the local lattice structure. This lattice distortion can increase the number of surface-active sites of the material and further optimize the catalytic properties of the material. The doping of oxygen atoms can also further optimize the electronic structure and surface chemistry of the material and enhance the synergistic effect between different metal elements, thus improving the overall catalytic performance of the material. Together, these mechanisms make HEOs show great potential for application in the field of OER. For instance, He et al. [76] developed nanoporous high entropy spinel oxide catalysts (Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2Cr0.2Mn0.2)3O4 (L-HEOs) with increased grain boundary densities using a novel low temperature solution combustion technique (Fig. 17 a). The nanoporous structure and enhanced grain boundary density contribute to improved OER performance, where the L-HEOs have an overpotential of 275 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Notably, these catalysts also demonstrate excellent long-term stability and maintain nearly constant overpotential over 10 h at 250 mA cm−2. This stability is attributed to the robust structural integrity provided by the HEO composition. Moreover, the interaction of oxygen with the transition metal (TM) can modulate the TM 3d and O 2p band gap energies, which optimizes the electronic structure of the material and improves its intrinsic OER activity. For example, Lao and his colleagues [77] incorporated various transition metals, including Fe, Cr, Mn, Mg, and Al, into (CoNiCuZn)O, resulting in the formation of five distinct pentavalent HEOs. Among these, (FeCoNiCuZn)O appeared as aggregated micro nano particles with a rough surface and porous structure. This particular HEO exhibited superior OER catalytic performance, featuring an overpotential of 323 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH. During the OER process, (FeCoNiCuZn)O experienced recombination, resulting in the generation of extra hydroxides that could serve as the actual active sites for the HEOs. However, the mechanism of surface remodeling has not been thoroughly explored in the studies, especially how surface remodeling affects the long-term stability and activity of the catalysts. In contrast, traditional catalysts such as RuO2, although having high activity, are prone to deactivation at high current densities and are costly. In contrast, HEOs are able to maintain a stable structure and performance during long-term operation due to their complex composition and high entropy effect, which significantly improves the durability of the catalysts. In addition, the multi-element composition of HEOs provides richer active sites, which makes them exhibit higher activity and selectivity in the OER process. Considering the high-entropy stabilization effect, the adjustable element combination/electronic structure, and the multifunctionality properties, nanostructured HEOs seem very promising as supports for ultrafine metal clusters, and the combination of the two systems may result in tunable multifunctional properties with a synergistic effect. For example, Jin et al. [78] developed a multicomponent nanoporous HEOs ((AlCoFeMoCr)3O4)/metal composite as a bifunctional ORR/OER electrocatalyst for the first time by a generic dealloying procedure. The ORR activity of the Pt clusters can be enhanced and stabilized through strong interaction with the nanoporous HEOs substrate, while the presence of Pt can improve the OER performance of HEO. The AlCoFeMoCr/Pt composite OER overpotential is only 260 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Although HEO catalysts exhibit excellent performance in OER, their dense crystal structure may limit the transport efficiency of reactants and products. To overcome this limitation, researchers have turned their attention to HELHs, which are identified as excellent OER catalysts not only by inheriting the high entropy properties of HEO, but also by having higher specific surface area and abundant active sites due to their open layered structure. As an example, Ding and colleagues [79] prepared HELH frameworks via in situ conversion using zinc and cobalt 2-methylimidazole (Fig. 17b). These frameworks demonstrated an overpotential of 259 mV at 100 mA cm−2, due to the inherited properties of the ZIF structure. The seamless single layer connections in the HELHs framework effectively prevent resistance increases after downsizing. Additionally, the structural design enhances electrolyte penetration and accelerates gas transport. Besides, Li et al. [80] recently developed an environmentally friendly method to synthesize HELHs nanosheets. By employing inexpensive metal foils and electrolytes as raw materials, they designed five components layered (oxy)hydroxide (CoFeNiCrV-LH) high entropy nanosheets. The formation of CoFeNiCrV-LH can be considered as a result of the stoichiometric doping of three coexisting heterogeneous metals (V, Cr and Ni) within the hydrotalc-like host layer of CoFe-LDH. These nanosheets demonstrated an overpotential of 232 mV at 10 mA cm−2. The excellent OER activity can be attributed to the synergistic effect of the high entropy effect and the increase in active surface area and the optimization of the structure resulting from the mild electrolytic synthetic process. In contrast, traditional doped catalysts, although having high activity, are prone to structural degradation during long-term operation, leading to performance degradation. The advantages of this method include its simplicity, the use of basic raw materials without the need for additional organic reagents or alkali metal salts, and the resulting nanosheets' unique properties. These nanosheets feature a hierarchical defect structure, low crystallinity, and large specific surface area, allowing the catalytic active sites to be fully utilized. Furthermore, by altering the composition of the metal foil, HELHs nanosheets with various components can be synthesized, offering broad structural tunability. HEOs and HELHs show promising applications in the fields of catalysis, energy storage and conversion by virtue of their unique oxygen/hydroxyl coordination environments, tunable electronic structures, and excellent chemical stability. However, they may suffer from insufficient conductivity or limited active sites under certain reducing environments or electrochemical conditions. Specifically, HELHs have abundant active sites due to their open layered structure can provide more reaction contact surfaces and active sites, thus improving the catalytic performance. However, under strong reducing environments, the metal elements in HELHs may undergo a valence change, resulting in some of the active sites being reduced to a low-valent or metallic state. This valence change alters the electronic structure of the material, which reduces its ability to adsorb reaction intermediates (e.g., *OH, O, and OOH), and thus reduces the number of active sites. Besides, Wu et al. [81] synthesized (FeCoNi)3(FeCr)-LDH using coprecipitation and hydrothermal method, in which Fe2+/Fe3+ coexisted, suggesting that certain metal sites may undergo valence changes due to reducing environments, which affects the stability of the active sites. In addition, a dense oxide layer may form on the surface of the HELHs during long-term electrochemical testing, which may hinder the contact of the reactants with the active sites and thus reduce the catalytic activity. However, current studies have mainly focused on demonstrating the synthetic versatility of HELHs and enhanced OER activity, and the stability of the active site under certain reducing or electrochemical conditions does require further investigation. In the future, in situ characterization studies under reducing conditions should be pursued to directly probe the stability of the active site. For example, in situ XPS, in situ Raman spectroscopy, and other techniques are used to monitor the changes in the surface structure and chemical state of HELHs in real time under reducing and electrochemical conditions. Through these studies, we hope to gain a deeper understanding of the mechanism of active site changes of HELHs under different conditions and provide theoretical support for optimizing the performance of HELHs. Based on the above problems, researchers are turning their attention to non-oxide systems such as HESs and HEPs, with a view to developing new HEMs with more stability and efficient catalytic properties. 3.3 High entropy sulfides Transition metal dichalcogenides are viewed as highly promising electrocatalysts for water splitting, as they enhance catalytic activity surface electronic structure regulation and active sites enrichment. However, it is important to note that metal chalcogenides, such as sulfides and selenides, are often considered pre-catalysts. During electrochemical oxidation, these chalcogenides convert into metal (oxy)hydroxides or oxides, which are believed to serve as the actual active centers. Sulfur can also be intentionally incorporated into metal (oxy)hydroxides, where its addition has been shown to significantly improve OER performance [82,83]. Like the oxygen atom, the sulfur atom also has a high electronegativity, which modulates the electronic structure and increases lattice distortion. In addition, the doping of sulfur atoms can promote the reconstruction of the surface of HEMs. During the OER reaction, the surface of the material undergoes dynamic changes, and the doping of sulfur atoms can guide this surface reconstruction process to form a surface structure that is more favorable for the reaction to proceed [84]. For example, the surface reconstruction can form surfaces rich in sulfur vacancies or hydroxyl groups, and these structures can serve as efficient active sites to improve the efficiency of the OER reaction. This in-depth understanding of the sulfur doping mechanism provides a theoretical basis for the design and synthesis of high-performance HESs. For instance, Li et al. [85] synthesized (MnFeCoNiCu)S2 nanoparticles using a solvothermal method with a MOF as a precursor, followed by vulcanization (Fig. 17c). Optimal sulfur doping modulates the electronic structure, enabling the synthesis of single-phase HEMS nanoparticles (<3 nm) with an enlarged active surface area for enhanced catalytic efficiency. Additionally, sulfurization fine-tunes the electronic states of metallic elements, further promoting synergistic multi-element interactions. As a result, these nanoparticles demonstrated exceptional OER capability, achieving an overpotential of 221 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH. Additionally, it is noteworthy that MOOH is likely the true active species for OER, with its interaction with SO4 2− further enhancing the catalytic efficiency. Similarly, Nguyen et al. [83] synthesized FeNiCoCrMnS2 using a solvothermal method, which exhibited excellent OER activity with an overpotential of 199 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. This study likewise found that during the OER, the sulfide was completely converted to MOOH, which proved to be the real active site, and its association with the remaining SO4 2− further enhanced the OER activity. This finding corroborates with that of Li et al. and reveals the key role of MOOH and SO4 2− in OER catalysis. In addition, Lin et al. [86] introduced novel non-equimolar HESs with an orthorhombic structure synthesized through one-step mechanochemical reaction. For example, HES-Mo, consisting of numerous small, irregularly shaped condensed crystals, exhibits outstanding catalytic viability for OER, with an overpotential of 303 mV at 10 mA cm−2. The improved performance is credited to the combined effect arising from the integration of various metals and metal sulfides, as well as the precise adjustment of the material's electronic state. In brief, when HESs serve as electrocatalysts, their surfaces undergo self-reconfiguration during the initial OER. The resulting metal (oxy)hydroxides are identified as the main active centers for OER, with residual sulfates further enhancing the catalytic performance. Moreover, the cocktail effect introduced by multiple metal and metal-sulfur interactions, as well as the tuning of the electronic states of the materials, can improve OER performance. 3.4 High entropy phosphides Although HESs exhibit excellent performance in OER catalysis, they may suffer from insufficient stability under certain extreme conditions, which has prompted researchers to turn their attention to other non-oxide systems, especially high entropy phosphides (HEPs). Similar to sulfides, HEPs demonstrate superior catalytic activity due to their unique charge states and excellent conductivity, making them highly promising electrocatalysts for water splitting. The phosphorus in phosphides, which has a larger atomic radius and higher electron donating capacity, thereby enables it to effectively modulate the electronic structure of the catalysts and thus improve the electrochemical performance. In addition, the abundant metal-phosphorus bonds formed by phosphorus doping enhanced the electronic conductivity and chemical stability of the catalysts, thus improving the catalytic activity [87,88]. P-doping-induced lattice distortion can also generate a large number of unsaturated coordination sites, and the simultaneous formation of the POM bridge bond network not only enhances the structural stability, but also builds an efficient electron transport channel. Research has shown that the strong synergistic interactions among multiple metal atoms in polymetallic phosphides result in significantly improved electrocatalytic efficiency compared to their monometallic counterparts. Analogous to HESs, HEPs pose considerable challenges in synthetic, resulting in limited reported studies on their characterization and applications [57]. To illustrate, He et al. [89] synthesized FeCoNiPdWP HEP nanoparticles via a mild colloidal approach. Remarkably, the HEP catalyst exhibited an exceptionally low OER overpotential of 227 mV at 10 mA cm−2, which was attributed to surface reconstruction into FeCoNiPdW high-entropy hydroxyl oxides with highly oxidized Fe, Co, and Ni species as active sites. Furthermore, Pd facilitated OH− adsorption, while W optimized oxygen intermediate adsorption through electronic structure modulation. However, while the study thoroughly discusses the surface reconstruction behavior during OER, it does not address how this restructuring impacts long-term catalyst stability. Given that surface reconstruction may induce irreversible structural changes, further investigation into its effect on durability is critical. Zhou et al. [90] utilized a high entropy metal–organic framework (HE-MOF) with Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, and Cu ions anchored on nickel foam as a self-sacrificing template. This template was then phosphorized to form a heterostructured amorphous FeCoNiCuMnP x /C composite. The resulting material exhibits a heterostructured fusiform morphology, with the HEPs encapsulated in a carbon layer, offering superior electron transport properties and a wealth of active sites for the OER. Furthermore, the presence of a locally ordered crystalline structure within the amorphous matrix significantly boosts the catalytic performance and durability. Consequently, the optimized FeCoNiCuMnP x /C composite achieves a low overpotential of 239 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 72.5 mV dec−1 for OER in an alkaline solution. Furthermore, electron transfer from metal atoms to phosphorus is observed, contributing to the enhanced catalytic performance. Moreover, Lai et al. [91] developed a one-step low temperature sol–gel method to prepare NiCoFeMnCrP nanoparticles embedded in a carbon matrix (Fig. 17d). In this process, NH4H2PO4 serves as the phosphorus source, promoting phosphide formation and creating an acidic environment to inhibit metal oxide formation. The exceptional catalytic performance of NiCoFeMnCrP for the OER is due to the synergistic interactions among its metal components. Specifically, it achieves a low overpotential of 270 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH. This remarkable activity is attributed to the tunable properties of phosphorus, which boost the adsorption of reaction intermediates. Overall, during electrocatalytic processes, the actual active sites of HEPs are the surface oxygen/hydroxide and phosphate species formed in situ during the OER. HEPs not only promote the formation of these reactive species but also suppress the generation of metal oxides. Additionally, the high electronegativity of phosphorus enables it to accept electrons from metal atoms, significantly enhancing catalytic performance. The presence of phosphorus also lowers the reaction energy barrier by modulating the adsorption energy of the reaction intermediates, further enhancing the OER efficiency. For optimal OER catalyst design, carefully adjusting the phosphorus to metal ratio is essential to achieve an ideal conductivity and performance. An optimal phosphorus content can enhance the material's conductivity and catalytic activity, whereas excessive phosphorus may induce structural instability or diminish active sites. Consequently, in designing HEPs, phosphorus incorporation must be carefully balanced to tailor the electronic structure, maximize synergistic effects, and optimize catalytic performance. 3.5 High entropy carbides Similarly, high entropy carbons (HECs) exhibit similar design concepts and performance advantages to HEPs. Carbon, like phosphorus, is highly electronegative and is capable of forming strong interactions with a variety of metal elements, thereby optimizing the electronic structure and catalytic activity of the material. When it is doped into the lattice, it breaks the original lattice symmetry and electron arrangement, and produces lattice distortion inside the material, thus increasing the number and activity of active sites. At the same time, the doping of carbon atoms will change the electronic structure of the HECs, regulate their surface charge distribution, enhance the interaction with the reactants, and thus accelerate the reaction rate. In addition, the HECs characterized by heterometallic bonding and long-range atomic order have garnered significant attention for OER due to their excellent conductivity, thermal stability, and highly tunable electronic properties. Unlike traditional materials, HECs exhibit a multicomponent eutectic structure consisting of multiple carbide phases. This structural diversity boosts entropy levels, enhancing their physical and chemical performance. Transition metals in HEC compositions predominantly belong to the IVB, VB, and VIB groups, with many forming ceramics that adopt rock salt structures. However, the development of HECs remains nascent, as synthesizing ceramic particles at relatively low temperatures poses a considerable challenge. For example, Bao et al. [92] successfully synthesized the HEC (ZrNbCrMoAl)C via a simple gel-based technique, and then subjected it to thermal processing at 700 °C in a nitrogen environment (Fig. 18 a). This process facilitated the conversion of organic materials into carbon. The resulting (ZrNbCrMoAl)C demonstrated excellent electrocatalytic properties during the OER, with an overpotential of 450 mV at 10 mA cm−2. This enhanced electrochemical behavior is due to the multi-element coordination among various metal and carbon and high electrical conductivity, which stems from the high entropy effect. This novel method opens up new possibilities for the economical preparation of HECs via low-temperature roasting. Although the (ZrNbCrMoAl)C exhibited some electrocatalytic performance, the performance was still unsatisfactory compared with some advanced electrocatalysts. The electrical conductivity of (ZrNbCrMoAl)C was 4.5 × 10−5 S cm−1, which was higher than that of medium entropy carbons, but the conductivity was still low compared with some advanced electrocatalysts. This may be due to the low conductivity caused by insufficient carbon content, which affects the catalytic performance. To explore the effect of carbon content on alloys, Liu et al. [93] modified the (Fe50Mn30Co10Cr10)100− x C x (x = 0, 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 6 at.%) alloy by incorporating varying amounts of carbon, extending previous studies. The as-cast (Fe50Mn30Co10Cr10)100− x C x displays reflections from both FCC and HCP phases. With increasing carbon content, the diffraction peak corresponding to the HCP phase weakens, while that of the FCC phase becomes more pronounced. The rise in carbon content strengthens the alloy through a combination of solution strengthening and carbide formation, leading to reduced plastic strain and improved yield strength. Compared with simple HEAs, HECs show better electrocatalytic OER performance due to the addition of carbon and the synergistic action of high-entropy multi-components. The introduction of carbon not only endows the materials with high electrical conductivity and thermal stability, but also optimizes the adsorption energy of the reaction intermediates by modulating the electronic structure, thus significantly enhancing the catalytic efficiency. This design concept of optimizing material properties through the synergistic interaction of non-metallic elements with multiple metallic elements is also applicable to other HEMs, such as high entropy nitrides (HENs). 3.6 High entropy nitrides Recently, high entropy nitrides (HENs), emerging as a new category of transition metal nitrides, have garnered attention as potential alternatives for OER. This is attributed to their good mechanical properties and high stability against chemicals. Nitrogen has a small atomic radius and high electronegativity. In HENs, it forms ionic or covalent bonds with many main group elements. This type of bonding makes the HEN structures more stable. The smaller atomic radius of nitrogen also enables it to be well embedded in the crystal structure composed of multiple main group elements, filling gaps, reducing lattice defects, and further enhancing the stability of the structure. In addition, nitrogen atoms can regulate the electrical conductivity of materials. If the nitrogen atom provides electrons, it will increase the electron concentration of the HENs, thus enhancing their conductivity. If the nitrogen atom attracts electrons, it will form holes and change the electrical behavior of the HENs. The HENs can narrow the d-band of the metals and change the filling state due to the nitriding process. Therefore, the electrical conductivity and catalytic performance are significantly enhanced. As an illustration, Zhu et al. [68] were the first to explore the OER performance of Ni-based high entropy anti-perovskite metal nitrides in alkaline solutions using chemical solution deposition techniques. Notably, the high entropy anti-perovskite metal nitride Cu0.5Fe0.5NNi2Co0.5Fe0.5 exhibited outstanding electrocatalytic OER capability, with an overpotential of 370 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and impressive long-term stability. The catalytic reaction kinetics were enhanced by the addition of nitrogen. These results point to a new approach for creating highly efficient catalysts based on high-entropy anti-perovskite nitrides. Suhr et al. [94] developed (Ti-Co-Mo-Ta-W)N thin film materials featuring continuous composition gradients, produced via reactive co-sputtering at 300 °C and 500 °C. Analysis revealed uniform nitrogen content across one composition library, with a decline in nitrogen concentration as deposition temperature increased: 30–40 at.% N relative to metal elements at 300 °C, compared to 26–35 at.% at 500 °C (Fig. 18b, c). The composition maps also indicated that higher nitrogen content was associated with increased Mo and reduced Co concentrations. Additionally, (Ti-Co-Mo-Ta-W)N exhibits favorable electrical characteristics, with a resistivity between 1.72 and 5.2 μΩ cm, and exhibited moderate OER activity. Thanks to their exceptional electrical conductivity, HENs surpass HEOs as promising candidates for electrocatalysts in future OER. Their complex structures and multicomponent elemental makeup provide a wider variety of active sites, effectively boosting reaction rates and overall catalytic efficiency. 3.7 High entropy borides High entropy borides (HEBs) are recognized for their exceptional OER activity. The inclusion of boron, characterized by its high electronegativity, improves OER performance by reducing metal–metal bonds and facilitating charge transfer for OOH species formation. Moreover, the strengthened adsorption of oxygen intermediates in HEBs further contributes to enhanced catalytic efficiency. Studies reveal that boron atoms in HEAs exist both as interstitial solutions and boride phases. Their seamless incorporation into the alloy matrix markedly improves the material's hardness, wear resistance, and oxidation resistance. As an example, Wang et al. [95] utilized a simple chemical reduction approach to prepare an amorphous HEB (CoFeNiMnZnB) with a uniformly distributed elemental composition (Fig. 18d, e). The synthesized CoFeNiMnZnB consists of porous particle clusters. Notably, this material exhibits outstanding oxygen evolution reactivity, with a low overpotential of 261 mV at 10 mA cm−2. The addition of boron, known for its high electronegativity, improves OER viability by reducing metal–metal bonding and promoting charge transfer for the generation of OOH intermediates. Overall, the exceptional OER performance of this HEB can be attributed to the combined effects of synergistic interactions among different metals, Zn ion leaching, the creation of oxygen vacancies, and the in situ formation of an amorphous oxyhydroxide layer on its surface during the reaction. Moreover, Liu et al. [96] proposed a “coordination-etch-reduction” strategy using Cu2O nanocubes as sacrificial templates to synthesize sheet–like FeCoCuMnRuB nanoboxes. The dense nanosheet array on the nanoboxes’ surface not only retains the benefits of two-dimensional morphology but also prevents nanosheet stacking, preserving the accessibility of active sites. The electron deficient boron acts as an electron trap, capturing delocalized electrons from adjacent metals and thereby facilitating the evolution of high valence active species (MII–OH → MIII–OOH). Additionally, the high entropy effect from the multiple metallic components creates multicenter active sites, mitigating the “traffic jam” effect caused by intermediates competing for a single active site and improving adsorption behavior. Consequently, FeCoCuMnRuB achieves enhanced OER performance, exhibiting a low overpotential of 233 mV at 10 mA cm−2. To sum up, HEBs represent a promising class of electrocatalysts, yet they have not garnered sufficient attention. As interstitial compounds, the small radius of boron atoms enables them to occupy interstitial sites within the metal lattice, maintaining the integrity of metal–metal bonding. Furthermore, the number of electrons, electronegativity, ionization energy, and distinctive outer electron configuration of boron contribute to a diverse range of bonding modes and strengths in transition metal borides. HEBs combine the high entropy effects of multi-component systems with the electron deficient nature of boron, rendering them highly promising candidates for catalytic energy storage applications. In summary, by precisely introducing heteroatoms (such as O, S, P, N, C, and B), the electronic structure and surface-active sites of the HEMs can be effectively regulated. However, the control of the elemental doping ratio is particularly critical. For example, too high phosphorus content can reduce the electrical conductivity, while insufficient doping makes it difficult to fully optimize the catalytic activity. Therefore, with the help of DFT calculations combined with machine learning methods, it is expected to achieve accurate prediction of elemental ratios and optimized design in the future. A comprehensive overview of the existing research is presented in Table S4 (Supporting Information). The inclusion of various non-metallic elements has significantly broadened the range and types of high entropy compounds, endowing these materials with exceptional properties that surpass those of conventional compounds. With continued research and performance optimization, HEMs hold immense potential for green energy technologies, opening up new possibilities for advancements and real-world applications in clean energy. However, the composition of HEMs is complex, involving the synergistic interactions of multiple elements, which makes the understanding of their catalytic mechanisms is still incomplete. Moreover, the synthetic methods for HEMs typically require harsh conditions and high cost, limiting their large-scale application. In terms of future development directions, researchers can develop more efficient and cost-effective synthetic methods to achieve large-scale production of high entropy compounds. In addition, it is necessary to conduct in-depth studies on the mechanisms of high entropy compounds in electrocatalytic OER to further enhance their catalytic performance. 4 The influence of four core effects of high entropy materials on OER performance The multi-elemental nature of high-entropy electrocatalysts introduces significant effects on the OER, effects that are less prominent in conventional electrocatalysts. Fig. 19 illustrates the four core effects and mechanisms of HEMs in the OER, including the high entropy effect, lattice distortion effect, cocktail effect and sluggish diffusion effect. These effects are closely related to the thermodynamics, structure, performance and kinetics of materials science, respectively, and work together to significantly enhance the OER performance of HEMs electrocatalysts [2,97]. Specifically, the high entropy effect enhances the thermodynamic stability of multi-element solid solutions, particularly at elevated temperatures [98,99]. Lattice distortion modifies structural attributes and influences both thermodynamic and kinetic behavior, affecting deformation and other properties. The cocktail effect, resulting from interactions among dissimilar atoms and severe lattice distortion, surpasses the predictions of the rule of mixtures (weighted average typically used to estimate composite material properties), leading to enhanced strength, toughness, fatigue resistance, creep resistance, and thermal and electrical conductivities. Meanwhile, the sluggish diffusion effect, by slowing atom kinetics, delays phase transformations, reflecting the combined influence of composition, crystal structure, and microstructure [100]. This helps to improve the thermal stability and mechanical properties of the material. Together, these effects significantly enhance the catalytic activity of HEMs in OER [101]. The following sections delve into these effects, examining their significance and impact on OER performance [102,103]. 4.1 High entropy effect The high entropy effect is crucial in the high entropy electrocatalysts by inhibiting the formation of stoichiometric compounds that typically exhibit highly ordered and brittle structures. Instead, it encourages the development of solid solution phases, significantly reducing the number of phases or crystal structures compared to predictions based on the Gibbs phase rule. According to this rule, the relationship P + F = C + 1 holds under constant pressure, where P represents the number of phases, F is the number of degrees of freedom, and C is the number of components in this system. This reduction in phase complexity simplifies the microstructure of high entropy electrocatalysts and promotes cooperative interactions between components. Therefore, the solid solution phases exhibit enhanced properties, including greater strength and ductility, largely attributed to the effects of solution hardening [104,105]. High entropy electrocatalysts with a solid solution phase offer several advantages that make them well-suited for OER performance. Firstly, they can be synthesized across a broad range of compositions that are unattainable in crystalline forms, enabling precise tuning of their electronic properties to satisfy catalytic reaction requirements. Secondly, their isotropic and homogeneous nature ensures that active sites exist within a chemically uniform environment. The single-phase structure and lack of surface element segregation in high entropy electrocatalysts facilitate a homogeneous distribution of active catalytic species, promoting high activity and selectivity. Finally, the high entropy effect is vital for stabilizing these catalysts. As the quantity of constituent elements grows, configurational entropy also rises, resulting in enhanced phase stability through the reduction of Gibbs free energy. This intrinsic stability underpins the long-term effectiveness and reliability of high entropy electrocatalysts in catalytic applications. To explore the fundamental link between configuration entropy and the OER mechanism, Tang et al. [106] synthesized a high entropy perovskite cobaltate containing five equimolar B-site metals (Mg, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni) through a straightforward sol–gel process (Fig. 20 a). They found that configurational entropy substantially boosts the activity of Co active sites and optimizes the OER mechanism (Fig. 20b). The high entropy cobaltate exhibited a low overpotential of only 320 mV at 10 mA cm−2, outperforming similar materials. This performance enhancement is ascribed to high configuration entropy, which results in a random distribution of cations, promotes surface reconstruction, and stabilizes surface oxygen vacancies (Fig. 20c). The study also confirmed that the high entropy electrocatalyst achieves rapid OER kinetics through a lattice oxygen mechanism. In addition, Gao et al. [103] developed a high entropy layered oxide FeCoMoW catalyst using the molten alkali technique. By incorporating high valence metals, they adjusted the electronic properties of the FeCo-based catalyst and enhanced its self-healing capacity, benefiting from the high entropy effect (Fig. 20d). The casual dispersion of metal atoms, prompted by high entropy, enables self-healing active sites to spontaneously fill metal vacancies on the two-dimensional hexagonal surface, rather than allowing them to escape. As a result, the FeCoMoW catalyst’s stability is improved (Fig. 20e). The two-dimensional FeCoMoW catalyst demonstrates outstanding self-healing ability under alkaline conditions, sustaining high OER activity over time. This self-healing catalyst delivers exceptional OER performance, achieving a notably lower overpotential in KBi solution after a 100 h stability test at 1.56 V and 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 20f). Within the framework of the OER, the high entropy effect can have several important impacts. Introducing multiple elements into the alloy results in a solid solution marked by considerable structural disorder. This disorder helps suppress the dissolution of individual metal species during OER, thereby improving the catalyst’s stability and durability under challenging electrochemical conditions. Additionally, the inherent complexity of HEAs encourages the creation of a diverse array of active sites on the catalyst’s surface, thereby enhancing the adsorption and activation of reactants. This results in improved catalytic efficiency, evidenced by lower overpotentials and higher OER activity. Altogether, the high entropy effect provides a compelling strategy for engineering robust and efficient OER catalysts for water electrolysis applications. 4.2 Lattice distortion effect HEMs often consist of solid solution phases that incorporate multiple principal elements. In these phases, every atom serves as a solute within the lattice [107]. This arrangement results in deviations from the average lattice positions, as atoms are surrounded by neighbors of varying sizes and differing bonding geometries, thereby causing lattice distortions. Lattice distortions affect the electrocatalytic OER activity. HEMs surfaces exhibit significant distortion due to the presence of diverse elements and dissimilar atomic pairs. This structural irregularity helps lower surface energy while generating active sites that enhance catalytic performance [108]. To investigate the impact of lattice distortion in HEMs on electrocatalytic reactions, Wang et al. [109] developed an FeCoNiMnRuLa/CNT catalyst that enhances water splitting by incorporating the rare earth element La, which disrupts the lattice order of FeCoNiMnRu (Fig. 21 a–c). The addition of La increases lattice distortion, which decreases the quantity of unpaired electrons in FeCoNiMnRu and accelerates the conversion of singlet oxygen-containing intermediates to triplet oxygen (Fig. 21d). DFT analysis confirms that this enhanced lattice distortion shifts the d-orbital electronic configuration of FeCoNiMnRu. As a result, Fe and Ni contribute significantly to the adsorption of *OH during the OER, while Ru, Co, and Mn ensure efficient desorption of oxygen-containing intermediates. This synergy results in outstanding activity and stability throughout water splitting, with FeCoNiMnRuLa/CNT achieving an overpotential of 281 mV at 10 mA cm−2. In addition to metal cation doping, which can promote lattice distortion, Chen et al. [110] introduced P-doped porous HEA electrodes with adjustable heteroatom content and lattice strain, effectively tuning their intrinsic electronic structure to enhance catalytic performance (Fig. 21e). Instead of forming phosphides, P-doping resulted in a graded tensile strain across the porous HEA structure (Fig. 21f). This strategy increased the number of exposed catalytic active sites, and also enhanced the intrinsic activity of the material. Consequently, the 1P-HEA electrode exhibited exceptional performance in alkaline HER and OER, with an overpotential of 70 mV and 211 mV at 10 mA cm−2, respectively. In brief, the lattice distortion effect induces atomic displacement and rearrangement on the catalyst surface, generating a large quantity of active sites that accelerate the kinetics of the OER. Additionally, this effect facilitates the improvement of the electron transport pathway within the catalyst, reducing charge transport resistance and ultimately boosting OER efficiency. 4.3 Cocktail effect The cocktail effect in HEMs underscores the improved properties resulting from multiple principal elements [111]. As atomic-scale composites, these materials exhibit the combined contributions of individual elements, their mutual interactions, and the microstructural influences these elements exert [112]. Although the cocktail effect is complex and not easily deciphered, identifying key factors before choosing materials and synthetic routes is vital for effective HEMs design. By harnessing this effect, researchers can advance the development of HEMs and expand synthetic strategies for catalytic applications [113]. For instance, Nan et al. [114] developed the yolk-shell La0.7Bi0.3Mn0.7− x Fe0.3Cu x O3 hollow spheres using a self-assembly solvothermal method and subsequent calcination (Fig. 22 a). Based on Hund's rules, Bi2+ (6p 1) and Fe2+ (3d 6) serve as electronic donors for Mn3+ (3d 4) and Cu2+ (3d 9), promoting robust electron coupling that drives double exchange interactions. To optimize these interactions and induce a cocktail effect in LaBiMnFeCu HEP x , the ratios of five non-equimolar elements were meticulously adjusted. Moreover, the La0.7Bi0.3Mn0.7− x Fe0.3Cu x O3 HEP, characterized by its large bond angles, short bond lengths, and G-type antiferromagnetic structure, enhances the electronic structure, which in turn accelerates electron exchange and promotes conductivity. As a result, this yolk-shell hollow sphere material exhibits the most pronounced cocktail effect and demonstrates the best catalytic activity for the OER (Fig. 22b). In addition to yolk-shell hollow spheres, the cocktail effect has also been explored in the field of hollow nanofibers. Hao et al. [115] employed an electrospinning method followed by calcination to synthesize La0.5Sr0.5Mn0.15Fe0.15Co0.4Ni0.15Cu0.15O3 high entropy perovskite oxide hollow nanofibers (LSMFCNC) for the OER (Fig. 22c, d). Driven by the “cocktail effect”, LSMFCNC exhibited remarkable OER performance and robust stability, achieving an overpotential of 309 mV at 10 mA cm−2. This effect was attributed to preferential OH adsorption on Fe, Cu, and Mn sites, as well as the facile formation of OO bonds on Cu sites. This phenomenon unveiled the “cocktail effect”, indicating that OH species bind preferentially to Fe, Cu, and Mn sites, while OO bonds form more readily on Cu sites. In a word, the cocktail effect impacts the OER by promoting the binding of key intermediate species, such as hydroxyl radicals (OH), on specific active sites within the catalyst structure. This enhanced binding affinity can facilitate the transfer of electrons and protons, accelerate the overall reaction rate, and improve the efficiency of oxygen evolution. Additionally, the cocktail effect can facilitate the formation of critical chemical bonds, such as OO bonds, which are essential intermediates in the OER mechanism. Overall, the cocktail effect represents a powerful strategy for designing advanced catalyst materials for the OER. By harnessing the synergies between different elements and optimizing their interactions within the catalyst structure, researchers can develop highly efficient, stable, and effective catalysts for facilitating the conversion of water into oxygen gas during electrochemical processes. 4.4 Sluggish diffusion effect In conventional alloys, atomic diffusion is usually a relatively fast process, especially at high temperatures. However, in HEMs, the atomic diffusion process becomes exceptionally complex due to the presence of a wide range of atoms with different sizes, electronegativities and bonding energies [19,116]. The interactions between these atoms and the presence of lattice distortions significantly increase the activation energy for atomic diffusion, which leads to a significant decrease in the atomic diffusion rate [102]. For example, the diffusion rate of elements in CoCrFeMnNi HEA is in the order of Mn > Cr > Fe > Co > Ni, and the diffusion coefficient of each element is lower than those of pure metals or conventional alloys at the same temperature [117,118]. This sluggish diffusion effect not only affects the microstructure of the material, but also influences the properties and applications. The sluggish diffusion effect plays a key role in the microstructure modulation of HEMs. Due to the slow diffusion of atoms, the phase transition process of materials at high temperatures is significantly inhibited [69,119]. The sluggish diffusion effect can be used to fine-tune the microstructure of the material by controlling the diffusion of atoms, for example, by forming fine precipitated phases in the alloy or inhibiting grain growth [15]. In addition, the sluggish diffusion effect can improve the mechanical properties of a material, such as hardness, strength and wear resistance, by inhibiting atomic diffusion. Due to the slow diffusion of atoms, it is more difficult for HEMs to deform plastically when subjected to force, thus increasing the material's resistance to deformation. Currently, most of the research on the sluggish diffusion effect is focused on the field of coatings of HEAs, especially in the application of high-temperature antioxidant and anti-ablative coatings [120]. For instance, Kuang et al. [121] prepared yttrium-modified high-entropy refractory metal silicide (Y4-HERMS) coating on a NbMoTaW HEA using a solid-phase diffusion method combined with the halide activated pack cementation (HAPC) technique. They tested the coating for ablation using an air plasma flame to simulate the extreme conditions experienced by hypersonic vehicles (Fig. 23 a). Due to the sluggish diffusion effect, after an ablation temperature of 2100 °C and an ablation duration of 180 s, the Y4-HERMS surface maintained a shiny appearance with a dense smooth oxide layer (Fig. 23b). DFT calculations show that the addition of Y promotes the formation of SiO2, strengthens the SiO bond, increases the viscosity of the SiO2 layer, and prevents O from diffusing into the metal silicide layer, improving the upper ablative resistance of the coating (Fig. 23c). Although the specific influence of the sluggish diffusion effect on OER performance has not been directly investigated, the sluggish diffusion effect has been widely studied in the field of electrochemistry. For instance, Zhou et al. [122] demonstrated a new enhancement mechanism, “migration retardation effect”, in high-entropy Li- and Mn-rich layered cathodes. They prepared a Li-rich layered oxide, HELRO, via oxalate co-precipitation and showed a more homogeneous strain distribution during cycling with smaller strain values, which was associated with less transition metal migration in HELRO (Fig. 23d). The energy landscapes of the continuous migration paths of Mn ions are illustrated in Fig. 23e. Mn ions in HELRO need to overcome a much higher energy barrier (0.93 eV) when migrating from site II to site III, whereas the energy barrier in LRO is only 0.05 eV (Fig. 23f), which suggests that the consecutive migration of Mn ions is significantly inhibited in HELRO. In addition, the average MnO bond length of HELRO (1.93 Å) is shorter than that of LRO (1.96 Å), suggesting stronger MnO covalency and higher bond strengths, which makes it necessary for Mn ions to overcome higher energy barriers during migration (Fig. 23g). Meanwhile, the MnO bond breaking energy of HELRO is higher than that of LRO (Fig. 23h), which implies that the MnO bond in HELRO is more difficult to break. The oxygen vacancy formation energy of HELRO is also higher than that of LRO (Fig. 23i), indicating that higher energy is required for the formation of oxygen vacancies in HELRO. This further confirms that the high-entropy design inhibits the formation of oxygen vacancies by enhancing the strength and stability of the MnO bond, thereby reducing the structural degradation and voltage decay associated with oxygen vacancies. By comparing the effects of different doping elements (e.g., Ni, Co, Mg, Cu, Ti, etc.) on the migration energy barriers of Mn ions, it can be found that the types and amounts of doping elements have significant effects on the migration energy barriers of Mn ions (Fig. 23j). In particular, the average migration energy barrier of HELRO is higher than that of any single-element doped LRO, indicating that the high-entropy design significantly inhibits the migration of Mn ions by synergistically enhancing the ionic and covalent nature of the MnO bond. Due to this sluggish diffusion effect, voltage degradation and capacity loss are reduced, significantly improving the structural stability and voltage holding capacity of HELRO. According to the current related research, it can be found that the sluggish diffusion effect of HEMs has many important advantages, such as higher recrystallization temperature, slower grain growth, and excellent thermal stability and creep resistance [117,118]. These advantages are beneficial in controlling the organization and properties of the alloys, resulting in better performance. This effect provides new ideas and methods for the design and application of HEMs, especially in the scenario of high temperature environment with high requirements on material properties, which has a broad application prospect. Despite the significant advantages of the sluggish diffusion effect in microstructure modulation and property enhancement of materials, it still faces some challenges in practical applications. For example, with the presence of multiple elements in HEMs, precise control of the diffusion rate of each element is a complex problem, and different elements have different diffusion coefficients that are affected by temperature, lattice distortion, and inter-element interactions. Therefore, we can combine computational simulations and experiments to precisely design the composition and structure of HEMs to optimize the diffusion rate. For example, by selecting combinations of elements with similar diffusion coefficients, differences in diffusion rates can be reduced, resulting in more homogeneous diffusion behavior. In addition, the properties of HEMs are further optimized for wider applications in electrocatalysis, coatings, high-temperature materials and so on. In summary, the four core effects collectively enhance the OER performance of HEMs. By leveraging these unique characteristics, researchers can further explore and optimize the design of HEMs for more efficient and sustainable electrocatalytic applications (Table S5, Supporting Information). Future studies should integrate advanced in situ characterization techniques (e.g., XAFS, XRD, and Raman spectroscopy) to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms governing HEMs in dynamic OER processes. In particular, time-resolved XAFS could track real-time evolution of active sites' electronic structure and coordination geometry, providing critical insights into: how the high-entropy effect stabilizes intermediate adsorption energetics and how lattice distortion modulates MO bond lengths/angles to optimize catalytic activity. Such mechanistic understanding would establish structure–property relationships essential for rational design of advanced HEM catalysts. Meanwhile, the in situ characterization can capture the key phenomena such as surface reconstruction or dynamic generation of oxygen vacancies during the reaction process, so as to analyze the synergistic effect of the four major effects at different stages of the reaction. In addition, we can establish the conformational relationship between key activity descriptors and catalytic performance. For example, the high entropy effect optimizes the electronic structure by regulating the d-band center position and charge transfer number, the lattice distortion effect creates strain active sites by changing the lattice strain and coordination number, the cocktail effect balances the adsorption free energy steps, and the sluggish diffusion effect stabilizes the oxygen vacancy formation energy. The regulation of catalytic reaction kinetics can be deeply revealed through the synergistic effect of multiple elements [123]. This progress will drive advancements in energy conversion and storage toward a greener and more sustainable future. 5 Conclusions and outlooks Since the introduction of the high entropy concept, the HEMs electrocatalysts for the OER have seen swift progress in a relatively short period. Particularly over the past ten years, there has been a sharp rise in the quantity of electrocatalysts documented in the literature, opening a new chapter in the development of OER electrocatalysts. This paper focuses on in-depth discussion the key factors in synthetic methods, compositions, and core effects on OER of HEMs. A review of these reports indicates that the critical elements in HEMs electrocatalyst research are the key factors in synthetic methods, including complexing agent, synthetic temperature, and calcination atmosphere. These factors can directly affect their structure and OER properties. Moreover, the relationship between composition and OER performance is emphasized. When it comes to optimizing the composition, the components of high entropy alloys and compounds formed with other heteroatoms (including O, S, P, N, C, and B) are used to enhance the chemical structure of active sites, which in turn improves the intrinsic kinetics of the OER. In addition, the electrocatalytic influence mechanism of the four core effects, including high entropy effect, lattice distortion effect, sluggish diffusion effect, and cocktail effect on OER performance are introduced. These effects can be fully leveraged to significantly enhance activity and stability. Nevertheless, the intricate nature of the multicomponent HEMs and their complicated interactions makes it highly challenging for the broader use of HEMs in electrocatalysis. The following section discusses the existing challenges and outlines future research directions for HEMs electrocatalysts. 5.1 Intelligent design of high entropy OER electrocatalysts (1) Computationally driven high-throughput screening. By integrating density functional theory (DFT), high throughput computation, and machine learning, the HEM electrocatalysts for OER with enhanced activity and stability can be efficiently screened. For example, the SP-ICP-MS technique can rapidly characterize the elemental distribution and size of nanoparticles to provide experimental data for computational models [124], and then combine density functional theory to provide convenient ideas for high-entropy catalysts. In addition, Chen et al. [125] successfully synthesized an iridium-free RuMnFeMoCo HEA with a low overpotential of only 170 mV at 10 mA cm−2. DFT calculations revealed that Mn, Fe, and Co sites substantially lowered the OER energy barrier while effectively modulating the overall catalytic activity. Furthermore, incorporating corrosion-resistant elements (Ru, Mo, and Co) significantly enhanced the catalyst's long-term stability. Furthermore, the electronic structure, oxidation state variations, and stability of various metal elements at catalytic sites can be predicted with the aid of computational tools, providing critical insights for optimized material design. (2) Intelligent self-adaptive electrocatalysts. The dynamic reconstruction behavior of high entropy OER electrocatalysts under electrolysis conditions is investigated to develop self-adaptive electrocatalysts capable of forming more active surface structures during reactions. For instance, Luan and his colleagues [126] revealed that the model CrMnFeCoNi alloy electrocatalyst undergoes dissolution on contact with the electrolyte during OER, depleting the surface of Cr, Mn, and Co. Subsequent cycling leads to the formation of amorphous NiFe-rich hydroxyl oxides on the surface, which promotes OER activity. As OER proceeds, dissolution and redeposition of Fe reduce the Ni/Fe ratio in the surface hydroxyl oxides, leading to a decrease in OER activity. Cr-rich oxides and oxygen-rich layers formed below the NiFe-rich hydroxyl oxides, hindering the diffusion and successive dissolution of Ni, Co, Mn, and Fe outward from the body. However, the destruction of the Cr-rich oxide layer due to continuous Cr dissolution leads to the exfoliation of the amorphous (oxygen) hydroxide layer. The fastest diffusing Mn is biased toward the surface, forming a Mn-rich oxide layer that leads to the decay of OER catalytic activity. Coordinated elementary processes disrupt high entropy atomic or electronic configurations by forming chemically and kinetically favorable (oxygen) hydroxides and oxides on the surface of the OER and on subsurface HEAs. Dynamic preferences can activate or deactivate HEA electrocatalysts. By integrating self-healing mechanisms, the durability and stability of the catalyst can be significantly improved, thereby extending its operational lifespan. 5.2 Composition/structural optimization and exploration of high efficiency catalytic mechanisms (1) Tunable composition optimization. Through element doping, defect engineering, and surface modification, the electronic structure and surface energy levels of the catalyst can be precisely tailored to enhance OER activity. By incorporating transition metals (like Ni, Co, Fe, Mn) with noble metals (such as Ir, Ru), HEMs can be formed to improve catalytic performance and corrosion resistance. For example, Li et al. [127] successfully synthesized rutile-type HEO catalysts (RuIrFeCoNi)O2 (IrRu-HEO) by a molten salt oxidation process, which was developed by introducing active enhancement elements (Fe, Co and Ni) into the matrix of iridium-ruthenium oxides. Influenced by the synergistic effect of multiple metals, IrRu-HEO exhibits excellent OER activity with a low overpotential of only 261 mV in 0.5 M H2SO4. In addition, the high entropy structure provides good stability and acid resistance. (2) Nanoscale, multi-Scale, interface engineering and heterostructures design. Atomic-level regulation, such as single-atom distribution, along with nanostructure optimization across 0D, 1D, 2D, 3D, porous and hollow structure design are employed to enhance the specific surface area and increase the density of active sites, thereby improving electron transport efficiency and reaction kinetics. Furthermore, the construction high entropy heterostructures optimizes electron transfer pathways, resulting in improved OER activity. For example, Hu et al. [128] in situ prepared FeCoNiMnCr HEA-HEO heterojunction catalyst via a Cr-induced spontaneous reconfiguration strategy with a low overpotential of 320 mV at 500 mA cm−2. The formation of HEA-HEO heterostructures can provide electroactive sites with robust valence states to ensure a long-term stable OER process for enhanced electroactivity. The incorporation of composite structures with materials such as MXenes and graphene further improves electrical conductivity, reduces overpotential, and enhances catalyst stability. (3) Electronic structure optimization and synergistic effects. The d-band center modulation of high-entropy OER catalysts is explored to enhance electron transfer capability and reduce the reaction energy barrier of OER. By utilizing Raman spectroscopy, in situ electrochemical XPS/XAFS, and other in situ characterization techniques, the adsorption energy of reaction intermediates can be further optimized, providing deeper insights into the catalytic mechanism and improving overall OER performance. 5.3 Sustainable development, low-cost manufacturing, and industrialization application (1) Low-cost, green synthetic and scalable fabrication. Develop the HEMs electrocatalysts based on transition metals (e.g., Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Mo) to decrease dependence on precious metals such as Ir and Ru. Promote the development of low-cost, high-activity, and high-stability OER catalysts to facilitate commercial applications. HEMs electrocatalysts are mainly composed of transition metal elements, which are abundant and low-cost. In contrast, conventional catalysts (e.g., IrO2 and RuO2) rely on rare and expensive noble metals, which limits their large-scale applications. As an example, the material cost of (FeCoNiMnCr)O x , a typical HEO, is much lower than that of commercial IrO2 (about $500 per gram) and RuO2 (about $140 per gram) [129]. Secondly, the high entropy effect gives the material excellent long-term stability, allowing it to operate stably for a long period of time with almost no current degradation even at high current densities, which significantly extends the service life of the electrolyze and reduces the cost of the catalyst. For practical water-splitting devices, HEMs electrocatalysts must meet key performance benchmarks, including high current density (>500 mA cm−2 at 1.8 V, overpotential <300 mV at 10 mA cm−2), long-term stability (stable operation for more than 1000 h at 100 mA cm−2 with almost no current degradation), and high energy efficiency (Faraday efficiency > 98 %). For the laboratory stage, wet chemical methods such as solvothermal and electrodeposition can be used to optimize catalyst performance. For the pilot stage, physical/chemical vapor deposition (PVD/CVD) and self-assembly technologies are recommended for continuous preparation of uniform HEMs and enable cost-effective and sustainable manufacturing. As for industrial production, efficient processes such as spray pyrolysis and fluidized bed reactor can be selected to achieve large-scale synthetic with ton capacity. Additionally, develop environmentally friendly synthetic methods, such as biotemplates and green solvents, to minimize environmental pollution during the scalable production of catalysts. (2) Recycling and reusability. Investigate recycling mechanisms for high-entropy OER electrocatalysts to enhance sustainability and promote resource efficiency. Optimize electrolyzer lifespan to minimize the long-term cost of catalysts, thereby improving their commercial viability and economic competitiveness in large-scale applications. For example, Li et al. [130] prepared NP-(FeCoNi)2Nb HEA catalysts with bilayer nanostructures using an electrochemical selective phase etching method. The synergistic effect of Fe, Co, Ni, and Nb elements in the outer amorphous HEO layer effectively reduces the energy barrier for the formation of intermediates, thus improving the catalytic activity. The amorphous NbO x in the inner layer supplements the dissolution of the Nb elements in the outer layer through outward diffusion, ensuring the high long-term activity of the catalyst (stable operation for more than 1600 h at 500 mA cm−2). Excitingly, the catalyst can be reactivated by simple electrochemical treatment to re-form the inner NbO x layer, which not only significantly extends its lifetime, but also reduces the cost. (3) Device integration and performance requirements. While the performance evaluation of HEM electrocatalysts in laboratory studies is usually based on the standard three-electrode system, HEM electrocatalysts need to meet more stringent requirements in practical application energy conversion devices (e.g., electrolyzers, fuel cells, etc.). Firstly, industrial-scale applications require catalysts to maintain high catalytic activity at high current density above 500 mA cm−2, which places higher standards on the electronic conductivity and mass transfer capabilities of the materials. Secondly, while laboratory tests usually require only a few hours of stability test, energy conversion devices (e.g., proton exchange membrane electrolyzers) require the catalyst to maintain continuous operational stability for tens of thousands of hours in strong acid or alkali environments, which puts high demands on the catalyst's corrosion resistance and structural stability. In addition, impurity poisoning effects in energy conversion devices (e.g., carbon monoxide adsorbs on the catalyst surface in fuel cells, hindering the oxidation reaction of hydrogen) may significantly reduce the catalytic efficiency, and laboratory environments are unable to simulate these complex factors. These differences highlight that when HEMs move from basic research to engineering applications, breakthroughs must be realized in high-throughput preparation processes, anti-poisoning design, and adaptability to practical applications. Future research should focus on building a complete research and development chain of “laboratory-pilot-industrialization”, in order to bridge the gap between basic research and practical application. In the future, it should be possible to develop scalable synthetic methods such as spray pyrolysis, etc., establish standardized preparation processes from grams to kilogram. Membrane electrode assemblies (MEAs) adapted to the properties of HEMs can also be designed to solve the interfacial contact and mass transfer problems in scale-up preparation. In addition, machine learning can be used to assist the screening of low-cost element combinations to guide the material design, and the development of waste catalyst recycling and regeneration processes. Through multidisciplinary collaborative innovation, the large-scale application of HEMs electrocatalysts in the field of energy conversion devices will eventually be realized. 5.4 Prospects of high entropy electrocatalysts in acidic OER Although this review mainly focuses on the OER performance of HEMs catalysts in alkaline environments, high entropy catalysts also show remarkable application prospects in the field of acidic OER. In recent years, some studies have begun to explore the OER performance of HEMs catalysts under acidic conditions. For example, Huang et al. [131] successfully prepared (RuSnSbReF)O x high entropy solid solutions with a rutile structure by the high temperature sintering technique. The architecture of the multicomponent rutile-structured Ru-based oxide acidic OER electrocatalyst is mainly to overcome the disadvantage of its poor stability while ensuring the electrocatalytic activity. The overpotential of the (RuSnSbReF)O x electrocatalyst was 156 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4 and a long-term determination of 213 h was possible at a current density of 100 mA cm−2. In addition, Yao et al. [132] prepared the sub-2 nm HEA nanoparticles featured with Ir-rich medium-entropy shell and a high-entropy core (IrRuCoNiMo@IrRuNiMoO x ), which exhibited an overpotential as low as 243 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4. More significantly, the MEA integrated with such IrRuCoNiMo@IrRuNiMoO x as anode exhibits the encouraging stability over 500 h at 1.0 A cm−2. These studies have shown that HEMs are also capable of stabilizing in acidic environments. However, the current research on HEMs in the field of acidic OER is still relatively small, and there are still many key issues to be solved. For example, how to further improve the stability of HEMs in acidic environments to meet the requirement of long catalyst life in practical applications; how to optimize the composition and structure of catalysts to achieve higher catalytic activity and selectivity; and how to deeply understand the reaction mechanism of HEMs in acidic OER processes. The solution of these problems will help to promote the wide application of HEMs in the field of acidic OER. To address the above problems, a series of effective optimization strategies have been proposed at present. Firstly, the introduction of corrosion-resistant elements (e.g., Ru, Mo, Ta) can form a protective oxide layer, which can effectively prevent the continuous dissolution of the material and improve its corrosion resistance in an acidic environment. Secondly, the construction of multilayer structures, such as core–shell structures or double-layer nanostructures, which inhibit the dissolution of surface-active components by means of the slow diffusion effect, can also effectively enhance their stability under acidic conditions. In addition, the preparation of low-dimensional HEMs, such as nanotubes and nanowires, is also a proven method. By increasing the specific surface area of the materials, not only their stability under acidic conditions can be improved, but also the catalytic performance can be further optimized. For example, one-dimensional HEOs nanoribbons exhibit excellent structural stability even at high temperatures and pressures as well as prolonged exposure to harsh acidic or alkaline chemical environments [133]. High entropy electrocatalysts for OER hold great potential to revolutionize energy conversion technologies. By integrating intelligent catalyst design, structural optimization, sustainable manufacturing, and industrial applications, these catalysts enable the development of next-generation high-efficiency, low-cost, and durable OER solutions. Their continued advancement will play a crucial role in promoting green hydrogen production, enhancing fuel cell performance, and accelerating the transition toward carbon–neutral energy systems. Her main research interests are focused on the application mechanisms of high-entropy materials in electrochemical energy storage and conversion. His research focuses on the interface between new energy storage materials and devices, mainly including high-energy density hybrid capacitor electrode materials, aqueous ion battery materials, micro-integrated energy storage devices, and flexible wearable energy storage devices. coredata.dc:description: High entropy materials (HEMs) show great potential as electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) thanks to their interesting four-core effect. This paper presents the first systematic summary of the key factors in the synthetic methods and their influence on the structure and OER properties of HEMs (including complexing agent, synthetic temperature, and calcination atmosphere). Optimizing the components of high entropy alloys and compounds by introducing heteroatoms (such as O, S, P, N, C, and B) can enhance the chemical configurations of active sites and thus enhance the intrinsic OER kinetics. In addition, this paper emphasizes the importance of the electrocatalytic influence mechanism of the four-core effects (including the high entropy effect, lattice distortion effect, cocktail effect and sluggish diffusion effect) on catalyst structure and their OER performance. Finally, we outline the current challenges and future development directions, aiming to offer crucial insights for creating economical and efficient HEM-based electrocatalysts in the OER field.
